p.verse: 1There was a man in the country of Uz named Job. He was a man of complete integrity, who feared God and turned away from evil.
2He had seven sons and three daughters.

3His estate included seven thousand sheep and goats, three thousand camels, five hundred yoke of oxen, five hundred female donkeys, and a very large number of servants. Job was the greatest man among all the people of the east.
4His sons used to take turns having banquets at their homes. They would send an invitation to their three sisters to eat and drink with them.

5Whenever a round of banqueting was over, Job would send for his children and purify them, rising early in the morning to offer burnt offerings for all of them. For Job thought, ‘Perhaps my children have sinned, having cursed God in their hearts.’ This was Job’s regular practice.
6One day the sons of God came to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them.
7The Lord asked Satan, ‘Where have you come from? ’

chapter.p: ‘From roaming through the earth,’ Satan answered him, ‘and walking around on it.’

p.verse: 8Then the Lord said to Satan, ‘Have you considered my servant Job? No one else on earth is like him, a man of perfect integrity, who fears God and turns away from evil.’
9Satan answered the Lord, ‘Does Job fear God for nothing?
10Haven’t you placed a hedge round him, his household, and everything he owns? You have blessed the work of his hands, and his possessions have increased in the land.
11But stretch out your hand and strike everything he owns, and he will surely curse you to your face.’
12‘Very well,’ the Lord told Satan, ‘everything he owns is in your power. However, do not lay a hand on Job himself.’ So Satan left the Lord’s presence.
13One day when Job’s sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house,
14a messenger came to Job and reported, ‘While the oxen were ploughing and the donkeys grazing nearby,
15the Sabeans swooped down and took them away. They struck down the servants with the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you! ’
16He was still speaking when another messenger came and reported, ‘God’s fire fell from heaven. It burned the sheep and the servants and devoured them, and I alone have escaped to tell you! ’

17That messenger was still speaking when yet another came and reported, ‘The Chaldeans formed three bands, made a raid on the camels, and took them away. They struck down the servants with the sword, and I alone have escaped to tell you! ’
18He was still speaking when another messenger came and reported, ‘Your sons and daughters were eating and drinking wine in their eldest brother’s house.
19Suddenly a powerful wind swept in from the desert and struck the four corners of the house. It collapsed on the young people so that they died, and I alone have escaped to tell you! ’
20Then Job stood up, tore his robe, and shaved his head. He fell to the ground and worshipped,
21saying:

poetryblock.poem: Naked I came from my mother’s womb,
and naked I will leave this life.
The Lord gives, and the Lord takes away.
Blessed be the name of the Lord.

p.verse: 22Throughout all this Job did not sin or blame God for anything.
1One day the sons of God came again to present themselves before the Lord, and Satan also came with them to present himself before the Lord.
2The Lord asked Satan, ‘Where have you come from? ’

chapter.p: ‘From roaming through the earth,’ Satan answered him, ‘and walking around on it.’

p.verse: 3Then the Lord said to Satan, ‘Have you considered my servant Job? No one else on earth is like him, a man of perfect integrity, who fears God and turns away from evil. He still retains his integrity, even though you incited me against him, to destroy him for no good reason.’
4‘Skin for skin! ’ Satan answered the Lord. ‘A man will give up everything he owns in exchange for his life.
5But stretch out your hand and strike his flesh and bones, and he will surely curse you to your face.’
6‘Very well,’ the Lord told Satan, ‘he is in your power; only spare his life.’
7So Satan left the Lord’s presence and infected Job with terrible boils from the soles of his feet to the top of his head.
8Then Job took a piece of broken pottery to scrape himself while he sat among the ashes.
9His wife said to him, ‘Are you still holding on to your integrity? Curse God and die! ’
10‘You speak as a foolish woman speaks,’ he told her. ‘Should we accept only good from God and not adversity? ’ Throughout all this Job did not sin in what he said.

11Now when Job’s three friends ​– ​Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite ​– ​heard about all this adversity that had happened to him, each of them came from his home. They met together to go and sympathise with him and comfort him.
12When they looked from a distance, they could barely recognise him. They wept aloud, and each man tore his robe and threw dust into the air and on his head.
13Then they sat on the ground with him for seven days and nights, but no one spoke a word to him because they saw that his suffering was very intense.
1After this, Job began to speak and cursed the day he was born.
2He said:

poem.verse: 3May the day I was born perish,

poetryblock.poem: and the night that said,
‘A boy is conceived.’

poem.verse: 4If only that day had turned to darkness!

poetryblock.poem: May God above not care about it,
or light shine on it.

poem.verse: 5May darkness and gloom reclaim it,

poetryblock.poem: and a cloud settle over it.
May what darkens the day terrify it.

poem.verse: 6If only darkness had taken that night away!

poetryblock.poem: May it not appear among the days of the year
or be listed in the calendar.

poem.verse: 7Yes, may that night be barren;

poetryblock.poem: may no joyful shout be heard in it.

poem.verse: 8Let those who curse days

poetryblock.poem: condemn it,
those who are ready to rouse Leviathan.

poem.verse: 9May its morning stars grow dark.

poetryblock.poem: May it wait for daylight but have none;
may it not see the breaking of dawn.

poem.verse: 10For that night did not shut

poetryblock.poem: the doors of my mother’s womb,
and hide sorrow from my eyes.

poem.verse: 11Why was I not stillborn;

poetryblock.poem: why didn’t I die as I came from the womb?

poem.verse: 12Why did the knees receive me,

poetryblock.poem: and why were there breasts for me to nurse at?

poem.verse: 13Now I would certainly be lying down in peace;

poetryblock.poem: I would be asleep.
Then I would be at rest

poem.verse: 14with the kings and counsellors of the earth,

poetryblock.poem: who rebuilt ruined cities for themselves,

poem.verse: 15or with princes who had gold,

poetryblock.poem: who filled their houses with silver.

poem.verse: 16Or why was I not hidden like a miscarried child,

poetryblock.poem: like infants who never see daylight?

poem.verse: 17There the wicked cease to make trouble,

poetryblock.poem: and there the weary find rest.

poem.verse: 18The captives are completely at rest;

poetryblock.poem: they do not hear a taskmaster’s voice.

poem.verse: 19Both small and great are there,

poetryblock.poem: and the slave is set free from his master.

poem.verse: 20Why is light given to one burdened with grief,

poetryblock.poem: and life to those whose existence is bitter,

poem.verse: 21who wait for death, but it does not come,

poetryblock.poem: and search for it more than for hidden treasure,

poem.verse: 22who are filled with much joy

poetryblock.poem: and are glad when they reach the grave?

poem.verse: 23Why is life given to a man whose path is hidden,

poetryblock.poem: whom God has hedged in?

poem.verse: 24I sigh when food is put before me,

poetryblock.poem: and my groans pour out like water.

poem.verse: 25For the thing I feared has overtaken me,

poetryblock.poem: and what I dreaded has happened to me.

poem.verse: 26I cannot relax or be calm;

poetryblock.poem: I have no rest, for turmoil has come.

p.verse: 1Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:

poem.verse: 2Should anyone try to speak with you

poetryblock.poem: when you are exhausted?
Yet who can keep from speaking?

poem.verse: 3Indeed, you have instructed many

poetryblock.poem: and have strengthened weak hands.

poem.verse: 4Your words have steadied the one who was stumbling

poetryblock.poem: and braced the knees that were buckling.

poem.verse: 5But now that this has happened to you,

poetryblock.poem: you have become exhausted.
It strikes you, and you are dismayed.

poem.verse: 6Isn’t your piety your confidence,

poetryblock.poem: and the integrity of your life your hope?

poem.verse: 7Consider: Who has perished when he was innocent?

poetryblock.poem: Where have the honest been destroyed?

poem.verse: 8In my experience, those who plough injustice

poetryblock.poem: and those who sow trouble reap the same.

poem.verse: 9They perish at a single blast from God

poetryblock.poem: and come to an end by the breath of his nostrils.

poem.verse: 10The lion may roar and the fierce lion growl,

poetryblock.poem: but the teeth of young lions are broken.

poem.verse: 11The strong lion dies if it catches no prey,

poetryblock.poem: and the cubs of the lioness are scattered.

poem.verse: 12A word was brought to me in secret;

poetryblock.poem: my ears caught a whisper of it.

poem.verse: 13Among unsettling thoughts from visions in the night,

poetryblock.poem: when deep sleep comes over men,

poem.verse: 14fear and trembling came over me

poetryblock.poem: and made all my bones shake.

poem.verse: 15I felt a draft on my face,

poetryblock.poem: and the hair on my body stood up.

poem.verse: 16A figure stood there,

poetryblock.poem: but I could not recognise its appearance;
a form loomed before my eyes.
I heard a whispering voice:

poem.verse: 17‘Can a mortal be righteous before God?

poetryblock.poem: Can a man be more pure than his Maker? ’

poem.verse: 18If God puts no trust in his servants

poetryblock.poem: and he charges his angels with foolishness,

poem.verse: 19how much more those who dwell in clay houses,

poetryblock.poem: whose foundation is in the dust,
who are crushed like a moth!

poem.verse: 20They are smashed to pieces from dawn to dusk;

poetryblock.poem: they perish for ever while no one notices.

poem.verse: 21Are their tent cords not pulled up?

poetryblock.poem: They die without wisdom.

poem.verse: 1Call out! Will anyone answer you?

poetryblock.poem: Which of the holy ones will you turn to?

poem.verse: 2For anger kills a fool,

poetryblock.poem: and jealousy slays the gullible.

poem.verse: 3I have seen a fool taking root,

poetryblock.poem: but I immediately pronounced a curse on his home.

poem.verse: 4His children are far from safety.

poetryblock.poem: They are crushed at the city gate,
with no one to rescue them.

poem.verse: 5The hungry consume his harvest,

poetryblock.poem: even taking it out of the thorns.
The thirsty pant for his children’s wealth.

poem.verse: 6For distress does not grow out of the soil,

poetryblock.poem: and trouble does not sprout from the ground.

poem.verse: 7But humans are born for trouble

poetryblock.poem: as surely as sparks fly upwards.

poem.verse: 8However, if I were you, I would appeal to God

poetryblock.poem: and would present my case to him.

poem.verse: 9He does great and unsearchable things,

poetryblock.poem: wonders without number.

poem.verse: 10He gives rain to the earth

poetryblock.poem: and sends water to the fields.

poem.verse: 11He sets the lowly on high,

poetryblock.poem: and mourners are lifted to safety.

poem.verse: 12He frustrates the schemes of the crafty

poetryblock.poem: so that they achieve no success.

poem.verse: 13He traps the wise in their craftiness

poetryblock.poem: so that the plans of the deceptive
are quickly brought to an end.

poem.verse: 14They encounter darkness by day,

poetryblock.poem: and they grope at noon
as if it were night.

poem.verse: 15He saves the needy from their sharp words

poetryblock.poem: and from the clutches of the powerful.

poem.verse: 16So the poor have hope,

poetryblock.poem: and injustice shuts its mouth.

poem.verse: 17See how happy is the person whom God corrects;

poetryblock.poem: so do not reject the discipline of the Almighty.

poem.verse: 18For he wounds but he also bandages;

poetryblock.poem: he strikes, but his hands also heal.

poem.verse: 19He will rescue you from six calamities;

poetryblock.poem: no harm will touch you in seven.

poem.verse: 20In famine he will redeem you from death,

poetryblock.poem: and in battle, from the power of the sword.

poem.verse: 21You will be safe from slander

poetryblock.poem: and not fear destruction when it comes.

poem.verse: 22You will laugh at destruction and hunger

poetryblock.poem: and not fear the land’s wild creatures.

poem.verse: 23For you will have a covenant with the stones of the field,

poetryblock.poem: and the wild animals will be at peace with you.

poem.verse: 24You will know that your tent is secure,

poetryblock.poem: and nothing will be missing when you inspect your home.

poem.verse: 25You will also know that your offspring will be many

poetryblock.poem: and your descendants like the grass of the earth.

poem.verse: 26You will approach the grave in full vigour,

poetryblock.poem: as a pile of sheaves is gathered in its season.

poem.verse: 27We have investigated this, and it is true!

poetryblock.poem: Hear it and understand it for yourself.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2If only my grief could be weighed

poetryblock.poem: and my devastation placed with it on the scales.

poem.verse: 3For then it would outweigh the sand of the seas!

poetryblock.poem: That is why my words are rash.

poem.verse: 4Surely the arrows of the Almighty have pierced me;

poetryblock.poem: my spirit drinks their poison.
God’s terrors are arrayed against me.

poem.verse: 5Does a wild donkey bray over fresh grass

poetryblock.poem: or an ox low over its fodder?

poem.verse: 6Is bland food eaten without salt?

poetryblock.poem: Is there flavour in an egg white?

poem.verse: 7I refuse to touch them;

poetryblock.poem: they are like contaminated food.

poem.verse: 8If only my request would be granted

poetryblock.poem: and God would provide what I hope for:

poem.verse: 9that he would decide to crush me,

poetryblock.poem: to unleash his power and cut me off!

poem.verse: 10It would still bring me comfort,

poetryblock.poem: and I would leap for joy in unrelenting pain
that I have not denied the words of the Holy One.

poem.verse: 11What strength do I have, that I should continue to hope?

poetryblock.poem: What is my future, that I should be patient?

poem.verse: 12Is my strength that of stone,

poetryblock.poem: or my flesh made of bronze?

poem.verse: 13Since I cannot help myself,

poetryblock.poem: the hope for success has been banished from me.

poem.verse: 14A despairing man should receive loyalty from his friends,

poetryblock.poem: even if he abandons the fear of the Almighty.

poem.verse: 15My brothers are as treacherous as a wadi,

poetryblock.poem: as seasonal streams that overflow

poem.verse: 16and become darkened because of ice,

poetryblock.poem: and the snow melts into them.

poem.verse: 17The wadis evaporate in warm weather;

poetryblock.poem: they disappear from their channels in hot weather.

poem.verse: 18Caravans turn away from their routes,

poetryblock.poem: go up into the desert, and perish.

poem.verse: 19The caravans of Tema look for these streams.

poetryblock.poem: The travelling merchants of Sheba hope for them.

poem.verse: 20They are ashamed because they had been confident of finding water.

poetryblock.poem: When they arrive there, they are disappointed.

poem.verse: 21So this is what you have now become to me.

poetryblock.poem: When you see something dreadful, you are afraid.

poem.verse: 22Have I ever said, ‘Give me something’

poetryblock.poem: or ‘Pay a bribe for me from your wealth’

poem.verse: 23or ‘Deliver me from the enemy’s hand’

poetryblock.poem: or ‘Redeem me from the hand of the ruthless’?

poem.verse: 24Teach me, and I will be silent.

poetryblock.poem: Help me understand what I did wrong.

poem.verse: 25How painful honest words can be!

poetryblock.poem: But what does your rebuke prove?

poem.verse: 26Do you think that you can disprove my words

poetryblock.poem: or that a despairing man’s words are mere wind?

poem.verse: 27No doubt you would cast lots for a fatherless child

poetryblock.poem: and negotiate a price to sell your friend.

poem.verse: 28But now, please look at me;

poetryblock.poem: I will not lie to your face.

poem.verse: 29Reconsider; don’t be unjust.

poetryblock.poem: Reconsider; my righteousness is still the issue.

poem.verse: 30Is there injustice on my tongue

poetryblock.poem: or can my palate not taste disaster?

poem.verse: 1Isn’t each person consigned to forced labour on earth?

poetryblock.poem: Are not his days like those of a hired worker?

poem.verse: 2Like a slave he longs for shade;

poetryblock.poem: like a hired worker he waits for his pay.

poem.verse: 3So I have been made to inherit months of futility,

poetryblock.poem: and troubled nights have been assigned to me.

poem.verse: 4When I lie down I think,

poetryblock.poem: ‘When will I get up? ’
But the evening drags on endlessly,
and I toss and turn until dawn.

poem.verse: 5My flesh is clothed with maggots and encrusted with dirt.

poetryblock.poem: My skin forms scabs and then oozes.

poem.verse: 6My days pass more swiftly than a weaver’s shuttle;

poetryblock.poem: they come to an end without hope.

poem.verse: 7Remember that my life is but a breath.

poetryblock.poem: My eye will never again see anything good.

poem.verse: 8The eye of anyone who looks on me

poetryblock.poem: will no longer see me.
Your eyes will look for me, but I will be gone.

poem.verse: 9As a cloud fades away and vanishes,

poetryblock.poem: so the one who goes down to Sheol will never rise again.

poem.verse: 10He will never return to his house;

poetryblock.poem: his home town will no longer remember him.

poem.verse: 11Therefore I will not restrain my mouth.

poetryblock.poem: I will speak in the anguish of my spirit;
I will complain in the bitterness of my soul.

poem.verse: 12Am I the sea or a sea monster,

poetryblock.poem: that you keep me under guard?

poem.verse: 13When I say, ‘My bed will comfort me,

poetryblock.poem: and my couch will ease my complaint,’

poem.verse: 14then you frighten me with dreams,

poetryblock.poem: and terrify me with visions,

poem.verse: 15so that I prefer strangling –

poetryblock.poem: death rather than life in this body.

poem.verse: 16I give up! I will not live for ever.

poetryblock.poem: Leave me alone, for my days are a breath.

poem.verse: 17What is a mere human, that you think so highly of him

poetryblock.poem: and pay so much attention to him?

poem.verse: 18You inspect him every morning,

poetryblock.poem: and put him to the test every moment.

poem.verse: 19Will you ever look away from me,

poetryblock.poem: or leave me alone long enough to swallow?

poem.verse: 20If I have sinned, what have I done to you,

poetryblock.poem: Watcher of humanity?
Why have you made me your target,
so that I have become a burden to you?

poem.verse: 21Why not forgive my sin

poetryblock.poem: and pardon my iniquity?
For soon I will lie down in the grave.
You will eagerly seek me, but I will be gone.

p.verse: 1Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:

poem.verse: 2How long will you go on saying these things?

poetryblock.poem: Your words are a blast of wind.

poem.verse: 3Does God pervert justice?

poetryblock.poem: Does the Almighty pervert what is right?

poem.verse: 4Since your children sinned against him,

poetryblock.poem: he gave them over to their rebellion.

poem.verse: 5But if you earnestly seek God

poetryblock.poem: and ask the Almighty for mercy,

poem.verse: 6if you are pure and upright,

poetryblock.poem: then he will move even now on your behalf
and restore the home where your righteousness dwells.

poem.verse: 7Then, even if your beginnings were modest,

poetryblock.poem: your final days will be full of prosperity.

poem.verse: 8For ask the previous generation,

poetryblock.poem: and pay attention to what their ancestors discovered,

poem.verse: 9since we were born only yesterday and know nothing.

poetryblock.poem: Our days on earth are but a shadow.

poem.verse: 10Will they not teach you and tell you

poetryblock.poem: and speak from their understanding?

poem.verse: 11Does papyrus grow where there is no marsh?

poetryblock.poem: Do reeds flourish without water?

poem.verse: 12While still uncut shoots,

poetryblock.poem: they would dry up quicker than any other plant.

poem.verse: 13Such is the destiny of all who forget God;

poetryblock.poem: the hope of the godless will perish.

poem.verse: 14His source of confidence is fragile;

poetryblock.poem: what he trusts in is a spider’s web.

poem.verse: 15He leans on his web, but it doesn’t stand firm.

poetryblock.poem: He grabs it, but it does not hold up.

poem.verse: 16He is a well-watered plant in the sunshine;

poetryblock.poem: his shoots spread out over his garden.

poem.verse: 17His roots are intertwined around a pile of rocks.

poetryblock.poem: He looks for a home among the stones.

poem.verse: 18If he is uprooted from his place,

poetryblock.poem: it will deny knowing him, saying, ‘I never saw you.’

poem.verse: 19Surely this is the joy of his way of life;

poetryblock.poem: yet others will sprout from the dust.

poem.verse: 20Look, God does not reject a person of integrity,

poetryblock.poem: and he will not support evildoers.

poem.verse: 21He will yet fill your mouth with laughter

poetryblock.poem: and your lips with a shout of joy.

poem.verse: 22Your enemies will be clothed with shame;

poetryblock.poem: the tent of the wicked will no longer exist.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2Yes, I know what you’ve said is true,

poetryblock.poem: but how can a person be justified before God?

poem.verse: 3If one wanted to take him to court,

poetryblock.poem: he could not answer God once in a thousand times.

poem.verse: 4God is wise and all-powerful.

poetryblock.poem: Who has opposed him and come out unharmed?

poem.verse: 5He removes mountains without their knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: overturning them in his anger.

poem.verse: 6He shakes the earth from its place

poetryblock.poem: so that its pillars tremble.

poem.verse: 7He commands the sun not to shine

poetryblock.poem: and seals off the stars.

poem.verse: 8He alone stretches out the heavens

poetryblock.poem: and treads on the waves of the sea.

poem.verse: 9He makes the stars: the Bear, Orion,

poetryblock.poem: the Pleiades, and the constellations of the southern sky.

poem.verse: 10He does great and unsearchable things,

poetryblock.poem: wonders without number.

poem.verse: 11If he passed by me, I wouldn’t see him;

poetryblock.poem: if he went by, I wouldn’t recognise him.

poem.verse: 12If he snatches something, who can stop him?

poetryblock.poem: Who can ask him, ‘What are you doing? ’

poem.verse: 13God does not hold back his anger;

poetryblock.poem: Rahab’s assistants cringe in fear beneath him!

poem.verse: 14How then can I answer him

poetryblock.poem: or choose my arguments against him?

poem.verse: 15Even if I were in the right, I could not answer.

poetryblock.poem: I could only beg my Judge for mercy.

poem.verse: 16If I summoned him and he answered me,

poetryblock.poem: I do not believe he would pay attention to what I said.

poem.verse: 17He batters me with a whirlwind

poetryblock.poem: and multiplies my wounds without cause.

poem.verse: 18He doesn’t let me catch my breath

poetryblock.poem: but fills me with bitter experiences.

poem.verse: 19If it is a matter of strength, look, he is the powerful one!

poetryblock.poem: If it is a matter of justice, who can summon him?

poem.verse: 20Even if I were in the right, my own mouth would condemn me;

poetryblock.poem: if I were blameless, my mouth would declare me guilty.

poem.verse: 21Though I am blameless,

poetryblock.poem: I no longer care about myself;
I renounce my life.

poem.verse: 22It is all the same. Therefore I say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘He destroys both the blameless and the wicked.’

poem.verse: 23When catastrophe brings sudden death,

poetryblock.poem: he mocks the despair of the innocent.

poem.verse: 24The earth is handed over to the wicked;

poetryblock.poem: he blindfolds its judges.
If it isn’t he, then who is it?

poem.verse: 25My days fly by faster than a runner;

poetryblock.poem: they flee without seeing any good.

poem.verse: 26They sweep by like boats made of papyrus,

poetryblock.poem: like an eagle swooping down on its prey.

poem.verse: 27If I said, ‘I will forget my complaint,

poetryblock.poem: change my expression, and smile,’

poem.verse: 28I would still live in terror of all my pains.

poetryblock.poem: I know you will not acquit me.

poem.verse: 29Since I will be found guilty,

poetryblock.poem: why should I struggle in vain?

poem.verse: 30If I wash myself with snow,

poetryblock.poem: and cleanse my hands with lye,

poem.verse: 31then you dip me in a pit of mud,

poetryblock.poem: and my own clothes despise me!

poem.verse: 32For he is not a man like me, that I can answer him,

poetryblock.poem: that we can take each other to court.

poem.verse: 33There is no mediator between us,

poetryblock.poem: to lay his hand on both of us.

poem.verse: 34Let him take his rod away from me

poetryblock.poem: so his terror will no longer frighten me.

poem.verse: 35Then I would speak and not fear him.

poetryblock.poem: But that is not the case; I am on my own.

poem.verse: 1I am disgusted with my life.

poetryblock.poem: I will give vent to my complaint
and speak in the bitterness of my soul.

poem.verse: 2I will say to God,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Do not declare me guilty!
Let me know why you prosecute me.

poem.verse: 3Is it good for you to oppress,

poetryblock.poem: to reject the work of your hands,
and favour the plans of the wicked?

poem.verse: 4Do you have eyes of flesh,

poetryblock.poem: or do you see as a human sees?

poem.verse: 5Are your days like those of a human,

poetryblock.poem: or your years like those of a man,

poem.verse: 6that you look for my iniquity

poetryblock.poem: and search for my sin,

poem.verse: 7even though you know that I am not wicked

poetryblock.poem: and that there is no one who can rescue from your power?

poem.verse: 8‘Your hands shaped me and formed me.

poetryblock.poem: Will you now turn and destroy me?

poem.verse: 9Please remember that you formed me like clay.

poetryblock.poem: Will you now return me to dust?

poem.verse: 10Did you not pour me out like milk

poetryblock.poem: and curdle me like cheese?

poem.verse: 11You clothed me with skin and flesh,

poetryblock.poem: and wove me together with bones and tendons.

poem.verse: 12You gave me life and faithful love,

poetryblock.poem: and your care has guarded my life.

poem.verse: 13‘Yet you concealed these thoughts in your heart;

poetryblock.poem: I know that this was your hidden plan:

poem.verse: 14if I sin, you would notice,

poetryblock.poem: and would not acquit me of my iniquity.

poem.verse: 15If I am wicked, woe to me!

poetryblock.poem: And even if I am righteous, I cannot lift up my head.
I am filled with shame
and have drunk deeply of my affliction.

poem.verse: 16If I am proud, you hunt me like a lion

poetryblock.poem: and again display your miraculous power against me.

poem.verse: 17You produce new witnesses against me

poetryblock.poem: and multiply your anger towards me.
Hardships assault me, wave after wave.

poem.verse: 18‘Why did you bring me out of the womb?

poetryblock.poem: I should have died and never been seen.

poem.verse: 19I wish I had never existed

poetryblock.poem: but had been carried from the womb to the grave.

poem.verse: 20Are my days not few? Stop it!

poetryblock.poem: Leave me alone, so that I can smile a little

poem.verse: 21before I go to a land of darkness and gloom,

poetryblock.poem: never to return.

poem.verse: 22It is a land of blackness like the deepest darkness,

poetryblock.poem: gloomy and chaotic,
where even the light is like the darkness.’

p.verse: 1Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:

poem.verse: 2Should this abundance of words go unanswered

poetryblock.poem: and such a talker be acquitted?

poem.verse: 3Should your babbling put others to silence,

poetryblock.poem: so that you can keep on ridiculing
with no one to humiliate you?

poem.verse: 4You have said, ‘My teaching is sound,

poetryblock.poem: and I am pure in your sight.’

poem.verse: 5But if only God would speak

poetryblock.poem: and open his lips against you!

poem.verse: 6He would show you the secrets of wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: for true wisdom has two sides.
Know then that God has chosen to overlook some of your iniquity.

poem.verse: 7Can you fathom the depths of God

poetryblock.poem: or discover the limits of the Almighty?

poem.verse: 8They are higher than the heavens ​– ​what can you do?

poetryblock.poem: They are deeper than Sheol ​– ​what can you know?

poem.verse: 9Their measure is longer than the earth

poetryblock.poem: and wider than the sea.

poem.verse: 10If he passes by and throws someone in prison

poetryblock.poem: or convenes a court, who can stop him?

poem.verse: 11Surely he knows which people are worthless.

poetryblock.poem: If he sees iniquity, will he not take note of it?

poem.verse: 12But a stupid person will gain understanding

poetryblock.poem: as soon as a wild donkey is born a human!

poem.verse: 13As for you, if you redirect your heart

poetryblock.poem: and spread out your hands to him in prayer –

poem.verse: 14if there is iniquity in your hand, remove it,

poetryblock.poem: and don’t allow injustice to dwell in your tents –

poem.verse: 15then you will hold your head high, free from fault.

poetryblock.poem: You will be firmly established and unafraid.

poem.verse: 16For you will forget your suffering,

poetryblock.poem: recalling it only as water that has flowed by.

poem.verse: 17Your life will be brighter than noonday;

poetryblock.poem: its darkness will be like the morning.

poem.verse: 18You will be confident, because there is hope.

poetryblock.poem: You will look carefully about and lie down in safety.

poem.verse: 19You will lie down with no one to frighten you,

poetryblock.poem: and many will seek your favour.

poem.verse: 20But the sight of the wicked will fail.

poetryblock.poem: Their way of escape will be cut off,
and their only hope is their last breath.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2No doubt you are the people,

poetryblock.poem: and wisdom will die with you!

poem.verse: 3But I also have a mind like you;

poetryblock.poem: I am not inferior to you.
Who doesn’t know the things you are talking about?

poem.verse: 4I am a laughing-stock to my friends,

poetryblock.poem: by calling on God, who answers me.
The righteous and blameless man is a laughing-stock.

poem.verse: 5The one who is at ease holds calamity in contempt

poetryblock.poem: and thinks it is prepared for those whose feet are slipping.

poem.verse: 6The tents of robbers are safe,

poetryblock.poem: and those who trouble God are secure;
God holds them in his hands.

poem.verse: 7But ask the animals, and they will instruct you;

poetryblock.poem: ask the birds of the sky, and they will tell you.

poem.verse: 8Or speak to the earth, and it will instruct you;

poetryblock.poem: let the fish of the sea inform you.

poem.verse: 9Which of all these does not know

poetryblock.poem: that the hand of the Lord has done this?

poem.verse: 10The life of every living thing is in his hand,

poetryblock.poem: as well as the breath of all humanity.

poem.verse: 11Doesn’t the ear test words

poetryblock.poem: as the palate tastes food?

poem.verse: 12Wisdom is found with the elderly,

poetryblock.poem: and understanding comes with long life.

poem.verse: 13Wisdom and strength belong to God;

poetryblock.poem: counsel and understanding are his.

poem.verse: 14Whatever he tears down cannot be rebuilt;

poetryblock.poem: whoever he imprisons cannot be released.

poem.verse: 15When he withholds water, everything dries up,

poetryblock.poem: and when he releases it, it destroys the land.

poem.verse: 16True wisdom and power belong to him.

poetryblock.poem: The deceived and the deceiver are his.

poem.verse: 17He leads counsellors away barefoot

poetryblock.poem: and makes judges go mad.

poem.verse: 18He releases the bonds put on by kings

poetryblock.poem: and fastens a belt round their waists.

poem.verse: 19He leads priests away barefoot

poetryblock.poem: and overthrows established leaders.

poem.verse: 20He deprives trusted advisers of speech

poetryblock.poem: and takes away the elders’ good judgement.

poem.verse: 21He pours out contempt on nobles

poetryblock.poem: and disarms the strong.

poem.verse: 22He reveals mysteries from the darkness

poetryblock.poem: and brings the deepest darkness into the light.

poem.verse: 23He makes nations great, then destroys them;

poetryblock.poem: he enlarges nations, then leads them away.

poem.verse: 24He deprives the world’s leaders of reason,

poetryblock.poem: and makes them wander in a trackless wasteland.

poem.verse: 25They grope around in darkness without light;

poetryblock.poem: he makes them stagger like a drunkard.

poem.verse: 1Look, my eyes have seen all this;

poetryblock.poem: my ears have heard and understood it.

poem.verse: 2Everything you know, I also know;

poetryblock.poem: I am not inferior to you.

poem.verse: 3Yet I prefer to speak to the Almighty

poetryblock.poem: and argue my case before God.

poem.verse: 4You use lies like plaster;

poetryblock.poem: you are all worthless healers.

poem.verse: 5If only you would shut up

poetryblock.poem: and let that be your wisdom!

poem.verse: 6Hear now my argument,

poetryblock.poem: and listen to my defence.

poem.verse: 7Would you testify unjustly on God’s behalf

poetryblock.poem: or speak deceitfully for him?

poem.verse: 8Would you show partiality to him

poetryblock.poem: or argue the case in his defence?

poem.verse: 9Would it go well if he examined you?

poetryblock.poem: Could you deceive him as you would deceive a man?

poem.verse: 10Surely he would rebuke you

poetryblock.poem: if you secretly showed partiality.

poem.verse: 11Would God’s majesty not terrify you?

poetryblock.poem: Would his dread not fall on you?

poem.verse: 12Your memorable sayings are proverbs of ash;

poetryblock.poem: your defences are made of clay.

poem.verse: 13Be quiet, and I will speak.

poetryblock.poem: Let whatever comes happen to me.

poem.verse: 14I will put myself at risk

poetryblock.poem: and take my life in my own hands.

poem.verse: 15Even if he kills me, I will hope in him.

poetryblock.poem: I will still defend my ways before him.

poem.verse: 16Yes, this will result in my deliverance,

poetryblock.poem: for no godless person can appear before him.

poem.verse: 17Pay close attention to my words;

poetryblock.poem: let my declaration ring in your ears.

poem.verse: 18Now then, I have prepared my case;

poetryblock.poem: I know that I am right.

poem.verse: 19Can anyone indict me?

poetryblock.poem: If so, I will be silent and die.

poem.verse: 20Only grant these two things to me, God,

poetryblock.poem: so that I will not have to hide from your presence:

poem.verse: 21remove your hand from me,

poetryblock.poem: and do not let your terror frighten me.

poem.verse: 22Then call, and I will answer,

poetryblock.poem: or I will speak, and you can respond to me.

poem.verse: 23How many iniquities and sins have I committed?

poetryblock.poem: Reveal to me my transgression and sin.

poem.verse: 24Why do you hide your face

poetryblock.poem: and consider me your enemy?

poem.verse: 25Will you frighten a wind-driven leaf?

poetryblock.poem: Will you chase after dry straw?

poem.verse: 26For you record bitter accusations against me

poetryblock.poem: and make me inherit the iniquities of my youth.

poem.verse: 27You put my feet in the stocks

poetryblock.poem: and stand watch over all my paths,
setting a limit for the soles of my feet.

poem.verse: 28A person wears out like something rotten,

poetryblock.poem: like a moth-eaten garment.

poem.verse: 1Anyone born of woman

poetryblock.poem: is short of days and full of trouble.

poem.verse: 2He blossoms like a flower, then withers;

poetryblock.poem: he flees like a shadow and does not last.

poem.verse: 3Do you really take notice of one like this?

poetryblock.poem: Will you bring me into judgement against you?

poem.verse: 4Who can produce something pure from what is impure?

poetryblock.poem: No one!

poem.verse: 5Since a person’s days are determined

poetryblock.poem: and the number of his months depends on you,
and since you have set limits he cannot pass,

poem.verse: 6look away from him and let him rest

poetryblock.poem: so that he can enjoy his day like a hired worker.

poem.verse: 7There is hope for a tree:

poetryblock.poem: If it is cut down, it will sprout again,
and its shoots will not die.

poem.verse: 8If its roots grow old in the ground

poetryblock.poem: and its stump starts to die in the soil,

poem.verse: 9the scent of water makes it thrive

poetryblock.poem: and produce twigs like a sapling.

poem.verse: 10But a person dies and fades away;

poetryblock.poem: he breathes his last ​– ​where is he?

poem.verse: 11As water disappears from a lake

poetryblock.poem: and a river becomes parched and dry,

poem.verse: 12so people lie down never to rise again.

poetryblock.poem: They will not wake up until the heavens are no more;
they will not stir from their sleep.

poem.verse: 13If only you would hide me in Sheol

poetryblock.poem: and conceal me until your anger passes.
If only you would appoint a time for me
and then remember me.

poem.verse: 14When a person dies, will he come back to life?

poetryblock.poem: If so, I would wait all the days of my struggle
until my relief comes.

poem.verse: 15You would call, and I would answer you.

poetryblock.poem: You would long for the work of your hands.

poem.verse: 16For then you would count my steps

poetryblock.poem: but would not take note of my sin.

poem.verse: 17My rebellion would be sealed up in a bag,

poetryblock.poem: and you would cover over my iniquity.

poem.verse: 18But as a mountain collapses and crumbles

poetryblock.poem: and a rock is dislodged from its place,

poem.verse: 19as water wears away stones

poetryblock.poem: and torrents wash away the soil from the land,
so you destroy a man’s hope.

poem.verse: 20You completely overpower him, and he passes away;

poetryblock.poem: you change his appearance and send him away.

poem.verse: 21If his sons receive honour, he does not know it;

poetryblock.poem: if they become insignificant, he is unaware of it.

poem.verse: 22He feels only the pain of his own body

poetryblock.poem: and mourns only for himself.

p.verse: 1Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:

poem.verse: 2Does a wise man answer with empty counsel

poetryblock.poem: or fill himself with the hot east wind?

poem.verse: 3Should he argue with useless talk

poetryblock.poem: or with words that serve no good purpose?

poem.verse: 4But you even undermine the fear of God

poetryblock.poem: and hinder meditation before him.

poem.verse: 5Your iniquity teaches you what to say,

poetryblock.poem: and you choose the language of the crafty.

poem.verse: 6Your own mouth condemns you, not I;

poetryblock.poem: your own lips testify against you.

poem.verse: 7Were you the first human ever born,

poetryblock.poem: or were you brought forth before the hills?

poem.verse: 8Do you listen in on the council of God,

poetryblock.poem: or have a monopoly on wisdom?

poem.verse: 9What do you know that we don’t?

poetryblock.poem: What do you understand that is not clear to us?

poem.verse: 10Both the grey-haired and the elderly are with us –

poetryblock.poem: older than your father.

poem.verse: 11Are God’s consolations not enough for you,

poetryblock.poem: even the words that deal gently with you?

poem.verse: 12Why has your heart misled you,

poetryblock.poem: and why do your eyes flash

poem.verse: 13as you turn your anger against God

poetryblock.poem: and allow such words to leave your mouth?

poem.verse: 14What is a mere human, that he should be pure,

poetryblock.poem: or one born of a woman, that he should be righteous?

poem.verse: 15If God puts no trust in his holy ones

poetryblock.poem: and the heavens are not pure in his sight,

poem.verse: 16how much less one who is revolting and corrupt,

poetryblock.poem: who drinks injustice like water?

poem.verse: 17Listen to me and I will inform you.

poetryblock.poem: I will describe what I have seen,

poem.verse: 18what the wise have declared and not concealed,

poetryblock.poem: that came from their ancestors,

poem.verse: 19to whom alone the land was given

poetryblock.poem: when no foreigner passed among them.

poem.verse: 20A wicked person writhes in pain all his days,

poetryblock.poem: throughout the number of years reserved for the ruthless.

poem.verse: 21Dreadful sounds fill his ears;

poetryblock.poem: when he is at peace, a robber attacks him.

poem.verse: 22He doesn’t believe he will return from darkness;

poetryblock.poem: he is destined for the sword.

poem.verse: 23He wanders about for food, asking, ‘Where is it? ’

poetryblock.poem: He knows the day of darkness is at hand.

poem.verse: 24Trouble and distress terrify him,

poetryblock.poem: overwhelming him like a king prepared for battle.

poem.verse: 25For he has stretched out his hand against God

poetryblock.poem: and has arrogantly opposed the Almighty.

poem.verse: 26He rushes headlong at him

poetryblock.poem: with his thick, studded shields.

poem.verse: 27Though his face is covered with fat

poetryblock.poem: and his waistline bulges with it,

poem.verse: 28he will dwell in ruined cities,

poetryblock.poem: in abandoned houses destined to become piles of rubble.

poem.verse: 29He will no longer be rich; his wealth will not endure.

poetryblock.poem: His possessions will not increase in the land.

poem.verse: 30He will not escape from the darkness;

poetryblock.poem: flames will wither his shoots,
and by the breath of God’s mouth, he will depart.

poem.verse: 31Let him not put trust in worthless things, being led astray,

poetryblock.poem: for what he gets in exchange will prove worthless.

poem.verse: 32It will be accomplished before his time,

poetryblock.poem: and his branch will not flourish.

poem.verse: 33He will be like a vine that drops its unripe grapes

poetryblock.poem: and like an olive tree that sheds its blossoms.

poem.verse: 34For the company of the godless will have no children,

poetryblock.poem: and fire will consume the tents of those who offer bribes.

poem.verse: 35They conceive trouble and give birth to evil;

poetryblock.poem: their womb prepares deception.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2I have heard many things like these.

poetryblock.poem: You are all miserable comforters.

poem.verse: 3Is there no end to your empty words?

poetryblock.poem: What provokes you that you continue testifying?

poem.verse: 4If you were in my place I could also talk like you.

poetryblock.poem: I could string words together against you
and shake my head at you.

poem.verse: 5Instead, I would encourage you with my mouth,

poetryblock.poem: and the consolation from my lips would bring relief.

poem.verse: 6If I speak, my suffering is not relieved,

poetryblock.poem: and if I hold back, does any of it leave me?

poem.verse: 7Surely he has now exhausted me.

poetryblock.poem: You have devastated my entire family.

poem.verse: 8You have shrivelled me up ​– ​it has become a witness;

poetryblock.poem: my frailty rises up against me and testifies to my face.

poem.verse: 9His anger tears at me, and he harasses me.

poetryblock.poem: He gnashes his teeth at me.
My enemy pierces me with his eyes.

poem.verse: 10They open their mouths against me

poetryblock.poem: and strike my cheeks with contempt;
they join themselves together against me.

poem.verse: 11God hands me over to the unjust;

poetryblock.poem: he throws me to the wicked.

poem.verse: 12I was at ease, but he shattered me;

poetryblock.poem: he seized me by the scruff of the neck
and smashed me to pieces.
He set me up as his target;

poem.verse: 13his archers surround me.

poetryblock.poem: He pierces my kidneys without mercy
and pours my bile on the ground.

poem.verse: 14He breaks through my defences again and again;

poetryblock.poem: he charges at me like a warrior.

poem.verse: 15I have sewn sackcloth over my skin;

poetryblock.poem: I have buried my strength in the dust.

poem.verse: 16My face has grown red with weeping,

poetryblock.poem: and darkness covers my eyes,

poem.verse: 17although my hands are free from violence

poetryblock.poem: and my prayer is pure.

poem.verse: 18Earth, do not cover my blood;

poetryblock.poem: may my cry for help find no resting place.

poem.verse: 19Even now my witness is in heaven,

poetryblock.poem: and my advocate is in the heights!

poem.verse: 20My friends scoff at me

poetryblock.poem: as I weep before God.

poem.verse: 21I wish that someone might argue for a man with God

poetryblock.poem: just as anyone would for a friend.

poem.verse: 22For only a few years will pass

poetryblock.poem: before I go the way of no return.

poem.verse: 1My spirit is broken.

poetryblock.poem: My days are extinguished.
A graveyard awaits me.

poem.verse: 2Surely mockers surround me,

poetryblock.poem: and my eyes must gaze at their rebellion.

poem.verse: 3Accept my pledge! Put up security for me.

poetryblock.poem: Who else will be my sponsor?

poem.verse: 4You have closed their minds to understanding,

poetryblock.poem: therefore you will not honour them.

poem.verse: 5If a man denounces his friends for a price,

poetryblock.poem: the eyes of his children will fail.

poem.verse: 6He has made me an object of scorn to the people;

poetryblock.poem: I have become a man people spit at.

poem.verse: 7My eyes have grown dim from grief,

poetryblock.poem: and my whole body has become but a shadow.

poem.verse: 8The upright are appalled at this,

poetryblock.poem: and the innocent are roused against the godless.

poem.verse: 9Yet the righteous person will hold to his way,

poetryblock.poem: and the one whose hands are clean will grow stronger.

poem.verse: 10But come back and try again, all of you.

poetryblock.poem: I will not find a wise man among you.

poem.verse: 11My days have slipped by;

poetryblock.poem: my plans have been ruined,
even the things dear to my heart.

poem.verse: 12They turned night into day

poetryblock.poem: and made light seem near in the face of darkness.

poem.verse: 13If I await Sheol as my home,

poetryblock.poem: spread out my bed in darkness,

poem.verse: 14and say to corruption, ‘You are my father,’

poetryblock.poem: and to the maggot, ‘My mother’ or ‘My sister,’

poem.verse: 15where then is my hope?

poetryblock.poem: Who can see any hope for me?

poem.verse: 16Will it go down to the gates of Sheol,

poetryblock.poem: or will we descend together to the dust?

p.verse: 1Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:

poem.verse: 2How long until you stop talking?

poetryblock.poem: Show some sense, and then we can talk.

poem.verse: 3Why are we regarded as cattle,

poetryblock.poem: as stupid in your sight?

poem.verse: 4You who tear yourself in anger –

poetryblock.poem: should the earth be abandoned on your account,
or a rock be removed from its place?

poem.verse: 5Yes, the light of the wicked is extinguished;

poetryblock.poem: the flame of his fire does not glow.

poem.verse: 6The light in his tent grows dark,

poetryblock.poem: and the lamp beside him is put out.

poem.verse: 7His powerful stride is shortened,

poetryblock.poem: and his own schemes trip him up.

poem.verse: 8For his own feet lead him into a net,

poetryblock.poem: and he strays into its mesh.

poem.verse: 9A trap catches him by the heel;

poetryblock.poem: a noose seizes him.

poem.verse: 10A rope lies hidden for him on the ground,

poetryblock.poem: and a snare waits for him along the path.

poem.verse: 11Terrors frighten him on every side

poetryblock.poem: and harass him at every step.

poem.verse: 12His strength is depleted;

poetryblock.poem: disaster lies ready for him to stumble.

poem.verse: 13Parts of his skin are eaten away;

poetryblock.poem: death’s firstborn consumes his limbs.

poem.verse: 14He is ripped from the security of his tent

poetryblock.poem: and marched away to the king of terrors.

poem.verse: 15Nothing he owned remains in his tent.

poetryblock.poem: Burning sulphur is scattered over his home.

poem.verse: 16His roots below dry up,

poetryblock.poem: and his branches above wither away.

poem.verse: 17All memory of him perishes from the earth;

poetryblock.poem: he has no name anywhere.

poem.verse: 18He is driven from light to darkness

poetryblock.poem: and chased from the inhabited world.

poem.verse: 19He has no children or descendants among his people,

poetryblock.poem: no survivor where he used to live.

poem.verse: 20Those in the west are appalled at his fate,

poetryblock.poem: while those in the east tremble in horror.

poem.verse: 21Indeed, such is the dwelling of the unjust man,

poetryblock.poem: and this is the place of the one who does not know God.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2How long will you torment me

poetryblock.poem: and crush me with words?

poem.verse: 3You have humiliated me ten times now,

poetryblock.poem: and you mistreat me without shame.

poem.verse: 4Even if it is true that I have sinned,

poetryblock.poem: my mistake concerns only me.

poem.verse: 5If you really want to appear superior to me

poetryblock.poem: and would use my disgrace as evidence against me,

poem.verse: 6then understand that it is God who has wronged me

poetryblock.poem: and caught me in his net.

poem.verse: 7I cry out, ‘Violence! ’ but get no response;

poetryblock.poem: I call for help, but there is no justice.

poem.verse: 8He has blocked my way so that I cannot pass through;

poetryblock.poem: he has veiled my paths with darkness.

poem.verse: 9He has stripped me of my honour

poetryblock.poem: and removed the crown from my head.

poem.verse: 10He tears me down on every side so that I am ruined.

poetryblock.poem: He uproots my hope like a tree.

poem.verse: 11His anger burns against me,

poetryblock.poem: and he regards me as one of his enemies.

poem.verse: 12His troops advance together;

poetryblock.poem: they construct a ramp against me
and camp round my tent.

poem.verse: 13He has removed my brothers from me;

poetryblock.poem: my acquaintances have abandoned me.

poem.verse: 14My relatives stop coming by,

poetryblock.poem: and my close friends have forgotten me.

poem.verse: 15My house guests and female servants regard me as a stranger;

poetryblock.poem: I am a foreigner in their sight.

poem.verse: 16I call for my servant, but he does not answer,

poetryblock.poem: even if I beg him with my own mouth.

poem.verse: 17My breath is offensive to my wife,

poetryblock.poem: and my own family finds me repulsive.

poem.verse: 18Even young boys scorn me.

poetryblock.poem: When I stand up, they mock me.

poem.verse: 19All of my best friends despise me,

poetryblock.poem: and those I love have turned against me.

poem.verse: 20My skin and my flesh cling to my bones;

poetryblock.poem: I have escaped with only the skin of my teeth.

poem.verse: 21Have mercy on me, my friends, have mercy,

poetryblock.poem: for God’s hand has struck me.

poem.verse: 22Why do you persecute me as God does?

poetryblock.poem: Will you never get enough of my flesh?

poem.verse: 23I wish that my words were written down,

poetryblock.poem: that they were recorded on a scroll

poem.verse: 24or were inscribed in stone for ever

poetryblock.poem: by an iron stylus and lead!

poem.verse: 25But I know that my Redeemer lives,

poetryblock.poem: and at the end he will stand on the dust.

poem.verse: 26Even after my skin has been destroyed,

poetryblock.poem: yet I will see God in my flesh.

poem.verse: 27I will see him myself;

poetryblock.poem: my eyes will look at him, and not as a stranger.
My heart longs within me.

poem.verse: 28If you say, ‘How will we pursue him,

poetryblock.poem: since the root of the problem lies with him? ’

poem.verse: 29then be afraid of the sword,

poetryblock.poem: because wrath brings punishment by the sword,
so that you may know there is a judgement.

p.verse: 1Then Zophar the Naamathite replied:

poem.verse: 2This is why my unsettling thoughts compel me to answer,

poetryblock.poem: because I am upset!

poem.verse: 3I have heard a rebuke that insults me,

poetryblock.poem: and my understanding makes me reply.

poem.verse: 4Don’t you know that ever since antiquity,

poetryblock.poem: from the time a human was placed on earth,

poem.verse: 5the joy of the wicked has been brief

poetryblock.poem: and the happiness of the godless has lasted only a moment?

poem.verse: 6Though his arrogance reaches heaven,

poetryblock.poem: and his head touches the clouds,

poem.verse: 7he will vanish for ever like his own dung.

poetryblock.poem: Those who know him will ask, ‘Where is he? ’

poem.verse: 8He will fly away like a dream and never be found;

poetryblock.poem: he will be chased away like a vision in the night.

poem.verse: 9The eye that saw him will see him no more,

poetryblock.poem: and his household will no longer see him.

poem.verse: 10His children will beg from the poor,

poetryblock.poem: for his own hands must give back his wealth.

poem.verse: 11His frame may be full of youthful vigour,

poetryblock.poem: but it will lie down with him in dust.

poem.verse: 12Though evil tastes sweet in his mouth

poetryblock.poem: and he conceals it under his tongue,

poem.verse: 13though he cherishes it and will not let it go

poetryblock.poem: but keeps it in his mouth,

poem.verse: 14yet the food in his stomach turns

poetryblock.poem: into cobras’ venom inside him.

poem.verse: 15He swallows wealth but must vomit it up;

poetryblock.poem: God will force it from his stomach.

poem.verse: 16He will suck the poison of cobras;

poetryblock.poem: a viper’s fangs will kill him.

poem.verse: 17He will not enjoy the streams,

poetryblock.poem: the rivers flowing with honey and curds.

poem.verse: 18He must return the fruit of his labour without consuming it;

poetryblock.poem: he doesn’t enjoy the profits from his trading.

poem.verse: 19For he oppressed and abandoned the poor;

poetryblock.poem: he seized a house he did not build.

poem.verse: 20Because his appetite is never satisfied,

poetryblock.poem: he does not let anything he desires escape.

poem.verse: 21Nothing is left for him to consume;

poetryblock.poem: therefore, his prosperity will not last.

poem.verse: 22At the height of his success distress will come to him;

poetryblock.poem: the full weight of misery will crush him.

poem.verse: 23When he fills his stomach,

poetryblock.poem: God will send his burning anger against him,
raining it down on him while he is eating.

poem.verse: 24If he flees from an iron weapon,

poetryblock.poem: an arrow from a bronze bow will pierce him.

poem.verse: 25He pulls it out of his back,

poetryblock.poem: the flashing tip out of his liver.
Terrors come over him.

poem.verse: 26Total darkness is reserved for his treasures.

poetryblock.poem: A fire unfanned by human hands will consume him;
it will feed on what is left in his tent.

poem.verse: 27The heavens will expose his iniquity,

poetryblock.poem: and the earth will rise up against him.

poem.verse: 28The possessions in his house will be removed,

poetryblock.poem: flowing away on the day of God’s anger.

poem.verse: 29This is the wicked person’s lot from God,

poetryblock.poem: the inheritance God ordained for him.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2Pay close attention to my words;

poetryblock.poem: let this be the consolation you offer.

poem.verse: 3Bear with me while I speak;

poetryblock.poem: then after I have spoken, you may continue mocking.

poem.verse: 4As for me, is my complaint against a human being?

poetryblock.poem: Then why shouldn’t I be impatient?

poem.verse: 5Look at me and shudder;

poetryblock.poem: put your hand over your mouth.

poem.verse: 6When I think about it, I am terrified

poetryblock.poem: and my body trembles in horror.

poem.verse: 7Why do the wicked continue to live,

poetryblock.poem: growing old and becoming powerful?

poem.verse: 8Their children are established while they are still alive,

poetryblock.poem: and their descendants, before their eyes.

poem.verse: 9Their homes are secure and free of fear;

poetryblock.poem: no rod from God strikes them.

poem.verse: 10Their bulls breed without fail;

poetryblock.poem: their cows calve and do not miscarry.

poem.verse: 11They let their little ones run around like lambs;

poetryblock.poem: their children skip about,

poem.verse: 12singing to the tambourine and lyre

poetryblock.poem: and rejoicing at the sound of the flute.

poem.verse: 13They spend their days in prosperity

poetryblock.poem: and go down to Sheol in peace.

poem.verse: 14Yet they say to God, ‘Leave us alone!

poetryblock.poem: We don’t want to know your ways.

poem.verse: 15Who is the Almighty, that we should serve him,

poetryblock.poem: and what will we gain by pleading with him? ’

poem.verse: 16But their prosperity is not of their own doing.

poetryblock.poem: The counsel of the wicked is far from me!

poem.verse: 17How often is the lamp of the wicked put out?

poetryblock.poem: Does disaster come on them?
Does he apportion destruction in his anger?

poem.verse: 18Are they like straw before the wind,

poetryblock.poem: like chaff a storm sweeps away?

poem.verse: 19God reserves a person’s punishment for his children.

poetryblock.poem: Let God repay the person himself, so that he may know it.

poem.verse: 20Let his own eyes see his demise;

poetryblock.poem: let him drink from the Almighty’s wrath!

poem.verse: 21For what does he care about his family once he is dead,

poetryblock.poem: when the number of his months has run out?

poem.verse: 22Can anyone teach God knowledge,

poetryblock.poem: since he judges the exalted ones?

poem.verse: 23One person dies in excellent health,

poetryblock.poem: completely secure and at ease.

poem.verse: 24His body is well fed,

poetryblock.poem: and his bones are full of marrow.

poem.verse: 25Yet another person dies with a bitter soul,

poetryblock.poem: having never tasted prosperity.

poem.verse: 26But they both lie in the dust,

poetryblock.poem: and worms cover them.

poem.verse: 27I know your thoughts very well,

poetryblock.poem: the schemes by which you would wrong me.

poem.verse: 28For you say, ‘Where now is the nobleman’s house? ’

poetryblock.poem: and ‘Where are the tents the wicked lived in? ’

poem.verse: 29Have you never consulted those who travel the roads?

poetryblock.poem: Don’t you accept their reports?

poem.verse: 30Indeed, the evil person is spared from the day of disaster,

poetryblock.poem: rescued from the day of wrath.

poem.verse: 31Who would denounce his behaviour to his face?

poetryblock.poem: Who would repay him for what he has done?

poem.verse: 32He is carried to the grave,

poetryblock.poem: and someone keeps watch over his tomb.

poem.verse: 33The soil on his grave is sweet to him.

poetryblock.poem: Everyone follows behind him,
and those who go before him are without number.

poem.verse: 34So how can you offer me such futile comfort?

poetryblock.poem: Your answers are deceptive.

p.verse: 1Then Eliphaz the Temanite replied:

poem.verse: 2Can a man be of any use to God?

poetryblock.poem: Can even a wise man be of use to him?

poem.verse: 3Does it delight the Almighty if you are righteous?

poetryblock.poem: Does he profit if you perfect your behaviour?

poem.verse: 4Does he correct you and take you to court

poetryblock.poem: because of your piety?

poem.verse: 5Isn’t your wickedness abundant

poetryblock.poem: and aren’t your iniquities endless?

poem.verse: 6For you took collateral from your brothers without cause,

poetryblock.poem: stripping off their clothes and leaving them naked.

poem.verse: 7You gave no water to the thirsty

poetryblock.poem: and withheld food from the famished,

poem.verse: 8while the land belonged to a powerful man

poetryblock.poem: and an influential man lived on it.

poem.verse: 9You sent widows away empty-handed,

poetryblock.poem: and the strength of the fatherless was crushed.

poem.verse: 10Therefore snares surround you,

poetryblock.poem: and sudden dread terrifies you,

poem.verse: 11or darkness, so you cannot see,

poetryblock.poem: and a flood of water covers you.

poem.verse: 12Isn’t God as high as the heavens?

poetryblock.poem: And look at the highest stars ​– ​how lofty they are!

poem.verse: 13Yet you say, ‘What does God know?

poetryblock.poem: Can he judge through total darkness?

poem.verse: 14Clouds veil him so that he cannot see,

poetryblock.poem: as he walks on the circle of the sky.’

poem.verse: 15Will you continue on the ancient path

poetryblock.poem: that wicked men have walked?

poem.verse: 16They were snatched away before their time,

poetryblock.poem: and their foundations were washed away by a river.

poem.verse: 17They were the ones who said to God, ‘Leave us alone! ’

poetryblock.poem: and ‘What can the Almighty do to us? ’

poem.verse: 18But it was he who filled their houses with good things.

poetryblock.poem: The counsel of the wicked is far from me!

poem.verse: 19The righteous see this and rejoice;

poetryblock.poem: the innocent mock them, saying,

poem.verse: 20‘Surely our opponents are destroyed,

poetryblock.poem: and fire has consumed what they left behind.’

poem.verse: 21Come to terms with God and be at peace;

poetryblock.poem: in this way good will come to you.

poem.verse: 22Receive instruction from his mouth,

poetryblock.poem: and place his sayings in your heart.

poem.verse: 23If you return to the Almighty, you will be renewed.

poetryblock.poem: If you banish injustice from your tent

poem.verse: 24and consign your gold to the dust,

poetryblock.poem: the gold of Ophir to the stones in the wadis,

poem.verse: 25the Almighty will be your gold

poetryblock.poem: and your finest silver.

poem.verse: 26Then you will delight in the Almighty

poetryblock.poem: and lift up your face to God.

poem.verse: 27You will pray to him, and he will hear you,

poetryblock.poem: and you will fulfil your vows.

poem.verse: 28When you make a decision, it will be carried out,

poetryblock.poem: and light will shine on your ways.

poem.verse: 29When others are humiliated and you say, ‘Lift them up,’

poetryblock.poem: God will save the humble.

poem.verse: 30He will even rescue the guilty one,

poetryblock.poem: who will be rescued by the purity of your hands.

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2Today also my complaint is bitter.

poetryblock.poem: His hand is heavy despite my groaning.

poem.verse: 3If only I knew how to find him,

poetryblock.poem: so that I could go to his throne.

poem.verse: 4I would plead my case before him

poetryblock.poem: and fill my mouth with arguments.

poem.verse: 5I would learn how he would answer me;

poetryblock.poem: and understand what he would say to me.

poem.verse: 6Would he prosecute me forcefully?

poetryblock.poem: No, he would certainly pay attention to me.

poem.verse: 7Then an upright man could reason with him,

poetryblock.poem: and I would escape from my Judge for ever.

poem.verse: 8If I go east, he is not there,

poetryblock.poem: and if I go west, I cannot perceive him.

poem.verse: 9When he is at work to the north, I cannot see him;

poetryblock.poem: when he turns south, I cannot find him.

poem.verse: 10Yet he knows the way I have taken;

poetryblock.poem: when he has tested me, I will emerge as pure gold.

poem.verse: 11My feet have followed in his tracks;

poetryblock.poem: I have kept to his way and not turned aside.

poem.verse: 12I have not departed from the commands from his lips;

poetryblock.poem: I have treasured the words from his mouth
more than my daily food.

poem.verse: 13But he is unchangeable; who can oppose him?

poetryblock.poem: He does what he desires.

poem.verse: 14He will certainly accomplish what he has decreed for me,

poetryblock.poem: and he has many more things like these in mind.

poem.verse: 15Therefore I am terrified in his presence;

poetryblock.poem: when I consider this, I am afraid of him.

poem.verse: 16God has made my heart faint;

poetryblock.poem: the Almighty has terrified me.

poem.verse: 17Yet I am not destroyed by the darkness,

poetryblock.poem: by the thick darkness that covers my face.

poem.verse: 1Why does the Almighty not reserve times for judgement?

poetryblock.poem: Why do those who know him never see his days?

poem.verse: 2The wicked displace boundary markers.

poetryblock.poem: They steal a flock and provide pasture for it.

poem.verse: 3They drive away the donkeys owned by the fatherless

poetryblock.poem: and take the widow’s ox as collateral.

poem.verse: 4They push the needy off the road;

poetryblock.poem: the poor of the land are forced into hiding.

poem.verse: 5Like wild donkeys in the wilderness,

poetryblock.poem: the poor go out to their task of foraging for food;
the desert provides nourishment for their children.

poem.verse: 6They gather their fodder in the field

poetryblock.poem: and glean the vineyards of the wicked.

poem.verse: 7Without clothing, they spend the night naked,

poetryblock.poem: having no covering against the cold.

poem.verse: 8Drenched by mountain rains,

poetryblock.poem: they huddle against the rocks, without shelter.

poem.verse: 9The fatherless infant is snatched from the breast;

poetryblock.poem: the nursing child of the poor is seized as collateral.

poem.verse: 10Without clothing, they wander about naked.

poetryblock.poem: They carry sheaves but go hungry.

poem.verse: 11They crush olives in their presses;

poetryblock.poem: they tread the winepresses, but go thirsty.

poem.verse: 12From the city, men groan;

poetryblock.poem: the mortally wounded cry for help,
yet God pays no attention to this crime.

poem.verse: 13The wicked are those who rebel against the light.

poetryblock.poem: They do not recognise its ways
or stay on its paths.

poem.verse: 14The murderer rises at dawn

poetryblock.poem: to kill the poor and needy,
and by night he becomes a thief.

poem.verse: 15The adulterer’s eye watches for twilight,

poetryblock.poem: thinking, ‘No eye will see me,’
and he covers his face.

poem.verse: 16In the dark they break into houses;

poetryblock.poem: by day they lock themselves in,
never experiencing the light.

poem.verse: 17For the morning is like darkness to them.

poetryblock.poem: Surely they are familiar with the terrors of darkness!

poem.verse: 18They float on the surface of the water.

poetryblock.poem: Their section of the land is cursed,
so that they never go to their vineyards.

poem.verse: 19As dry ground and heat snatch away the melted snow,

poetryblock.poem: so Sheol steals those who have sinned.

poem.verse: 20The womb forgets them;

poetryblock.poem: worms feed on them;
they are remembered no more.
So injustice is broken like a tree.

poem.verse: 21They prey on the childless woman who is unable to conceive,

poetryblock.poem: and do not deal kindly with the widow.

poem.verse: 22Yet God drags away the mighty by his power;

poetryblock.poem: when he rises up, they have no assurance of life.

poem.verse: 23He gives them a sense of security, so they can rely on it,

poetryblock.poem: but his eyes watch over their ways.

poem.verse: 24They are exalted for a moment, then gone;

poetryblock.poem: they are brought low and shrivel up like everything else.
They wither like ears of corn.

poem.verse: 25If this is not true, then who can prove me a liar

poetryblock.poem: and show that my speech is worthless?

p.verse: 1Then Bildad the Shuhite replied:

poem.verse: 2Dominion and dread belong to him,

poetryblock.poem: the one who establishes harmony in his heights.

poem.verse: 3Can his troops be numbered?

poetryblock.poem: Does his light not shine on everyone?

poem.verse: 4How can a human be justified before God?

poetryblock.poem: How can one born of woman be pure?

poem.verse: 5If even the moon does not shine

poetryblock.poem: and the stars are not pure in his sight,

poem.verse: 6how much less a human, who is a maggot,

poetryblock.poem: a son of man, who is a worm!

p.verse: 1Then Job answered:

poem.verse: 2How you have helped the powerless

poetryblock.poem: and delivered the arm that is weak!

poem.verse: 3How you have counselled the unwise

poetryblock.poem: and abundantly provided insight!

poem.verse: 4With whom did you speak these words?

poetryblock.poem: Whose breath came out of your mouth?

poem.verse: 5The departed spirits tremble

poetryblock.poem: beneath the waters and all that inhabit them.

poem.verse: 6Sheol is naked before God,

poetryblock.poem: and Abaddon has no covering.

poem.verse: 7He stretches the northern skies over empty space;

poetryblock.poem: he hangs the earth on nothing.

poem.verse: 8He wraps up the water in his clouds,

poetryblock.poem: yet the clouds do not burst beneath its weight.

poem.verse: 9He obscures the view of his throne,

poetryblock.poem: spreading his cloud over it.

poem.verse: 10He laid out the horizon on the surface of the waters

poetryblock.poem: at the boundary between light and darkness.

poem.verse: 11The pillars that hold up the sky tremble,

poetryblock.poem: astounded at his rebuke.

poem.verse: 12By his power he stirred the sea,

poetryblock.poem: and by his understanding he crushed Rahab.

poem.verse: 13By his breath the heavens gained their beauty;

poetryblock.poem: his hand pierced the fleeing serpent.

poem.verse: 14These are but the fringes of his ways;

poetryblock.poem: how faint is the word we hear of him!
Who can understand his mighty thunder?

p.verse: 1Job continued his discourse, saying:

poem.verse: 2As God lives, who has deprived me of justice,

poetryblock.poem: and the Almighty who has made me bitter,

poem.verse: 3as long as my breath is still in me

poetryblock.poem: and the breath from God remains in my nostrils,

poem.verse: 4my lips will not speak unjustly,

poetryblock.poem: and my tongue will not utter deceit.

poem.verse: 5I will never affirm that you are right.

poetryblock.poem: I will maintain my integrity until I die.

poem.verse: 6I will cling to my righteousness and never let it go.

poetryblock.poem: My conscience will not accuse me as long as I live!

poem.verse: 7May my enemy be like the wicked

poetryblock.poem: and my opponent like the unjust.

poem.verse: 8For what hope does the godless person have when he is cut off,

poetryblock.poem: when God takes away his life?

poem.verse: 9Will God hear his cry

poetryblock.poem: when distress comes on him?

poem.verse: 10Will he delight in the Almighty?

poetryblock.poem: Will he call on God at all times?

poem.verse: 11I will teach you about God’s power.

poetryblock.poem: I will not conceal what the Almighty has planned.

poem.verse: 12All of you have seen this for yourselves,

poetryblock.poem: why do you keep up this empty talk?

poem.verse: 13This is a wicked man’s lot from God,

poetryblock.poem: the inheritance the ruthless receive from the Almighty.

poem.verse: 14Even if his children increase, they are destined for the sword;

poetryblock.poem: his descendants will never have enough food.

poem.verse: 15Those who survive him will be buried by the plague,

poetryblock.poem: yet their widows will not weep for them.

poem.verse: 16Though he piles up silver like dust

poetryblock.poem: and heaps up fine clothing like clay –

poem.verse: 17he may heap it up, but the righteous will wear it,

poetryblock.poem: and the innocent will divide up his silver.

poem.verse: 18The house he built is like a moth’s cocoon

poetryblock.poem: or a shelter set up by a watchman.

poem.verse: 19He lies down wealthy, but will do so no more;

poetryblock.poem: when he opens his eyes, it is gone.

poem.verse: 20Terrors overtake him like a flood;

poetryblock.poem: a storm wind sweeps him away at night.

poem.verse: 21An east wind picks him up, and he is gone;

poetryblock.poem: it carries him away from his place.

poem.verse: 22It blasts at him without mercy,

poetryblock.poem: while he flees desperately from its force.

poem.verse: 23It claps its hands at him

poetryblock.poem: and scoffs at him from its place.

poem.verse: 1Surely there is a mine for silver

poetryblock.poem: and a place where gold is refined.

poem.verse: 2Iron is taken from the ground,

poetryblock.poem: and copper is smelted from ore.

poem.verse: 3A miner puts an end to the darkness;

poetryblock.poem: he probes the deepest recesses
for ore in the gloomy darkness.

poem.verse: 4He cuts a shaft far from human habitation,

poetryblock.poem: in places unknown to those who walk above ground.
Suspended far away from people,
the miners swing back and forth.

poem.verse: 5Food may come from the earth,

poetryblock.poem: but below the surface the earth is transformed as by fire.

poem.verse: 6Its rocks are a source of lapis lazuli,

poetryblock.poem: containing flecks of gold.

poem.verse: 7No bird of prey knows that path;

poetryblock.poem: no falcon’s eye has seen it.

poem.verse: 8Proud beasts have never walked on it;

poetryblock.poem: no lion has ever prowled over it.

poem.verse: 9The miner uses a flint tool

poetryblock.poem: and turns up ore from the root of the mountains.

poem.verse: 10He cuts out channels in the rocks,

poetryblock.poem: and his eyes spot every treasure.

poem.verse: 11He dams up the streams from flowing

poetryblock.poem: so that he may bring to light what is hidden.

poem.verse: 12But where can wisdom be found,

poetryblock.poem: and where is understanding located?

poem.verse: 13No one can know its value,

poetryblock.poem: since it cannot be found in the land of the living.

poem.verse: 14The ocean depths say, ‘It’s not in me,’

poetryblock.poem: while the sea declares, ‘I don’t have it.’

poem.verse: 15Gold cannot be exchanged for it,

poetryblock.poem: and silver cannot be weighed out for its price.

poem.verse: 16Wisdom cannot be valued in the gold of Ophir,

poetryblock.poem: in precious onyx or lapis lazuli.

poem.verse: 17Gold and glass do not compare with it,

poetryblock.poem: and articles of fine gold cannot be exchanged for it.

poem.verse: 18Coral and quartz are not worth mentioning.

poetryblock.poem: The price of wisdom is beyond pearls.

poem.verse: 19Topaz from Cush cannot compare with it,

poetryblock.poem: and it cannot be valued in pure gold.

poem.verse: 20Where then does wisdom come from,

poetryblock.poem: and where is understanding located?

poem.verse: 21It is hidden from the eyes of every living thing

poetryblock.poem: and concealed from the birds of the sky.

poem.verse: 22Abaddon and Death say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘We have heard news of it with our ears.’

poem.verse: 23But God understands the way to wisdom,

poetryblock.poem: and he knows its location.

poem.verse: 24For he looks to the ends of the earth

poetryblock.poem: and sees everything under the heavens.

poem.verse: 25When God fixed the weight of the wind

poetryblock.poem: and distributed the water by measure,

poem.verse: 26when he established a limit for the rain

poetryblock.poem: and a path for the lightning,

poem.verse: 27he considered wisdom and evaluated it;

poetryblock.poem: he established it and examined it.

poem.verse: 28He said to mankind,

poetryblock.poem: ‘The fear of the Lord ​– ​that is wisdom.
And to turn from evil is understanding.’

p.verse: 1Job continued his discourse, saying:

poem.verse: 2If only I could be as in months gone by,

poetryblock.poem: in the days when God watched over me,

poem.verse: 3when his lamp shone above my head,

poetryblock.poem: and I walked through darkness by his light!

poem.verse: 4I would be as I was in the days of my youth

poetryblock.poem: when God’s friendship rested on my tent,

poem.verse: 5when the Almighty was still with me

poetryblock.poem: and my children were around me,

poem.verse: 6when my feet were bathed in curds

poetryblock.poem: and the rock poured out streams of oil for me!

poem.verse: 7When I went out to the city gate

poetryblock.poem: and took my seat in the town square,

poem.verse: 8the young men saw me and withdrew,

poetryblock.poem: while older men stood to their feet.

poem.verse: 9City officials stopped talking

poetryblock.poem: and covered their mouths with their hands.

poem.verse: 10The noblemen’s voices were hushed,

poetryblock.poem: and their tongues stuck to the roof of their mouths.

poem.verse: 11When they heard me, they blessed me,

poetryblock.poem: and when they saw me, they spoke well of me.

poem.verse: 12For I rescued the poor who cried out for help,

poetryblock.poem: and the fatherless child who had no one to support him.

poem.verse: 13The dying blessed me,

poetryblock.poem: and I made the widow’s heart rejoice.

poem.verse: 14I clothed myself in righteousness,

poetryblock.poem: and it enveloped me;
my just decisions were like a robe and a turban.

poem.verse: 15I was eyes to the blind

poetryblock.poem: and feet to the lame.

poem.verse: 16I was a father to the needy,

poetryblock.poem: and I examined the case of the stranger.

poem.verse: 17I shattered the fangs of the unjust

poetryblock.poem: and snatched the prey from his teeth.

poem.verse: 18So I thought, ‘I will die in my own nest

poetryblock.poem: and multiply my days as the sand.

poem.verse: 19My roots will have access to water,

poetryblock.poem: and the dew will rest on my branches all night.

poem.verse: 20My whole being will be refreshed within me,

poetryblock.poem: and my bow will be renewed in my hand.’

poem.verse: 21Men listened to me with expectation,

poetryblock.poem: waiting silently for my advice.

poem.verse: 22After a word from me they did not speak again;

poetryblock.poem: my speech settled on them like dew.

poem.verse: 23They waited for me as for the rain

poetryblock.poem: and opened their mouths as for spring showers.

poem.verse: 24If I smiled at them, they couldn’t believe it;

poetryblock.poem: they were thrilled at the light of my countenance.

poem.verse: 25I directed their course and presided as chief.

poetryblock.poem: I lived as a king among his troops,
like one who comforts those who mourn.

poem.verse: 1But now they mock me,

poetryblock.poem: men younger than I am,
whose fathers I would have refused to put
with my sheep dogs.

poem.verse: 2What use to me was the strength of their hands?

poetryblock.poem: Their vigour had left them.

poem.verse: 3Emaciated from poverty and hunger,

poetryblock.poem: they gnawed the dry land,
the desolate wasteland by night.

poem.verse: 4They plucked mallow among the shrubs,

poetryblock.poem: and the roots of the broom tree were their food.

poem.verse: 5They were banished from human society;

poetryblock.poem: people shouted at them as if they were thieves.

poem.verse: 6They are living on the slopes of the wadis,

poetryblock.poem: among the rocks and in holes in the ground.

poem.verse: 7They bray among the shrubs;

poetryblock.poem: they huddle beneath the thistles.

poem.verse: 8Foolish men, without even a name.

poetryblock.poem: They were forced to leave the land.

poem.verse: 9Now I am mocked by their songs;
