poetryblock.poem: I have become an object of scorn to them.

poem.verse: 10They despise me and keep their distance from me;

poetryblock.poem: they do not hesitate to spit in my face.

poem.verse: 11Because God has loosened my bowstring and oppressed me,

poetryblock.poem: they have cast off restraint in my presence.

poem.verse: 12The rabble rise up at my right;

poetryblock.poem: they trap my feet
and construct their siege ramp against me.

poem.verse: 13They tear up my path;

poetryblock.poem: they contribute to my destruction,
without anyone to help them.

poem.verse: 14They advance as through a gaping breach;

poetryblock.poem: they keep rolling in through the ruins.

poem.verse: 15Terrors are turned loose against me;

poetryblock.poem: they chase my dignity away like the wind,
and my prosperity has passed by like a cloud.

poem.verse: 16Now my life is poured out before me,

poetryblock.poem: and days of suffering have seized me.

poem.verse: 17Night pierces my bones,

poetryblock.poem: but my gnawing pains never rest.

poem.verse: 18My clothing is distorted with great force;

poetryblock.poem: he chokes me by the neck of my garment.

poem.verse: 19He throws me into the mud,

poetryblock.poem: and I have become like dust and ashes.

poem.verse: 20I cry out to you for help, but you do not answer me;

poetryblock.poem: when I stand up, you merely look at me.

poem.verse: 21You have turned against me with cruelty;

poetryblock.poem: you harass me with your strong hand.

poem.verse: 22You lift me up on the wind and make me ride it;

poetryblock.poem: you scatter me in the storm.

poem.verse: 23Yes, I know that you will lead me to death –

poetryblock.poem: the place appointed for all who live.

poem.verse: 24Yet no one would stretch out his hand

poetryblock.poem: against a ruined person
when he cries out to him for help
because of his distress.

poem.verse: 25Have I not wept for those who have fallen on hard times?

poetryblock.poem: Has my soul not grieved for the needy?

poem.verse: 26But when I hoped for good, evil came;

poetryblock.poem: when I looked for light, darkness came.

poem.verse: 27I am churning within and cannot rest;

poetryblock.poem: days of suffering confront me.

poem.verse: 28I walk about blackened, but not by the sun.

poetryblock.poem: I stood in the assembly and cried out for help.

poem.verse: 29I have become a brother to jackals

poetryblock.poem: and a companion of ostriches.

poem.verse: 30My skin blackens and flakes off,

poetryblock.poem: and my bones burn with fever.

poem.verse: 31My lyre is used for mourning

poetryblock.poem: and my flute for the sound of weeping.

poem.verse: 1I have made a covenant with my eyes.

poetryblock.poem: How then could I look at a young woman?

poem.verse: 2For what portion would I have from God above,

poetryblock.poem: or what inheritance from the Almighty on high?

poem.verse: 3Doesn’t disaster come to the unjust

poetryblock.poem: and misfortune to evildoers?

poem.verse: 4Does he not see my ways

poetryblock.poem: and number all my steps?

poem.verse: 5If I have walked in falsehood

poetryblock.poem: or my foot has rushed to deceit,

poem.verse: 6let God weigh me on accurate scales,

poetryblock.poem: and he will recognise my integrity.

poem.verse: 7If my step has turned from the way,

poetryblock.poem: my heart has followed my eyes,
or impurity has stained my hands,

poem.verse: 8let someone else eat what I have sown,

poetryblock.poem: and let my crops be uprooted.

poem.verse: 9If my heart has gone astray over a woman

poetryblock.poem: or I have lurked at my neighbour’s door,

poem.verse: 10let my own wife grind grain for another man,

poetryblock.poem: and let other men sleep with her.

poem.verse: 11For that would be a disgrace;

poetryblock.poem: it would be an iniquity deserving punishment.

poem.verse: 12For it is a fire that consumes down to Abaddon;

poetryblock.poem: it would destroy my entire harvest.

poem.verse: 13If I have dismissed the case of my male or female servants

poetryblock.poem: when they made a complaint against me,

poem.verse: 14what could I do when God stands up to judge?

poetryblock.poem: How should I answer him when he calls me to account?

poem.verse: 15Did not the one who made me in the womb also make them?

poetryblock.poem: Did not the same God form us both in the womb?

poem.verse: 16If I have refused the wishes of the poor

poetryblock.poem: or let the widow’s eyes go blind,

poem.verse: 17if I have eaten my few crumbs alone

poetryblock.poem: without letting the fatherless eat any of it –

poem.verse: 18for from my youth, I brought him up as his father,

poetryblock.poem: and since the day I was born I guided the widow –

poem.verse: 19if I have seen anyone dying for lack of clothing

poetryblock.poem: or a needy person without a cloak,

poem.verse: 20if he did not bless me

poetryblock.poem: while warming himself with the fleece from my sheep,

poem.verse: 21if I ever cast my vote against a fatherless child

poetryblock.poem: when I saw that I had support in the city gate,

poem.verse: 22then let my shoulder blade fall from my back,

poetryblock.poem: and my arm be pulled from its socket.

poem.verse: 23For disaster from God terrifies me,

poetryblock.poem: and because of his majesty I could not do these things.

poem.verse: 24If I placed my confidence in gold

poetryblock.poem: or called fine gold my trust,

poem.verse: 25if I have rejoiced because my wealth is great

poetryblock.poem: or because my own hand has acquired so much,

poem.verse: 26if I have gazed at the sun when it was shining

poetryblock.poem: or at the moon moving in splendour,

poem.verse: 27so that my heart was secretly enticed

poetryblock.poem: and I threw them a kiss,

poem.verse: 28this would also be an iniquity deserving punishment,

poetryblock.poem: for I would have denied God above.

poem.verse: 29Have I rejoiced over my enemy’s distress,

poetryblock.poem: or become excited when trouble came his way?

poem.verse: 30I have not allowed my mouth to sin

poetryblock.poem: by asking for his life with a curse.

poem.verse: 31Haven’t the members of my household said,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Who is there who has not had enough to eat at Job’s table? ’

poem.verse: 32No stranger had to spend the night on the street,

poetryblock.poem: for I opened my door to the traveller.

poem.verse: 33Have I covered my transgressions as others do

poetryblock.poem: by hiding my iniquity in my heart

poem.verse: 34because I greatly feared the crowds

poetryblock.poem: and because the contempt of the clans terrified me,
so I grew silent and would not go outside?

poem.verse: 35If only I had someone to hear my case!

poetryblock.poem: Here is my signature; let the Almighty answer me.
Let my Opponent compose his indictment.

poem.verse: 36I would surely carry it on my shoulder

poetryblock.poem: and wear it like a crown.

poem.verse: 37I would give him an account of all my steps;

poetryblock.poem: I would approach him like a prince.

poem.verse: 38If my land cries out against me

poetryblock.poem: and its furrows join in weeping,

poem.verse: 39if I have consumed its produce without payment

poetryblock.poem: or shown contempt for its tenants,

poem.verse: 40then let thorns grow instead of wheat

poetryblock.poem: and stinkweed instead of barley.

chapter.p: The words of Job are concluded.

p.verse: 1So these three men ceased answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
2Then Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite from the family of Ram became angry. He was angry at Job because he had justified himself rather than God.
3He was also angry at Job’s three friends because they had failed to refute him and yet had condemned him.
4Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job because they were all older than he.
5But when he saw that the three men could not answer Job, he became angry.
6So Elihu son of Barachel the Buzite replied:

poetryblock.poem: I am young in years,
while you are old;
therefore I was timid and afraid
to tell you what I know.

poem.verse: 7I thought that age should speak

poetryblock.poem: and maturity should teach wisdom.

poem.verse: 8But it is the spirit in a person –

poetryblock.poem: the breath from the Almighty –
that gives anyone understanding.

poem.verse: 9It is not only the old who are wise

poetryblock.poem: or the elderly who understand how to judge.

poem.verse: 10Therefore I say, ‘Listen to me.

poetryblock.poem: I too will declare what I know.’

poem.verse: 11Look, I waited for your conclusions;

poetryblock.poem: I listened to your insights
as you sought for words.

poem.verse: 12I paid close attention to you.

poetryblock.poem: Yet no one proved Job wrong;
not one of you refuted his arguments.

poem.verse: 13So do not claim, ‘We have found wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: let God deal with him, not man.’

poem.verse: 14But Job has not directed his argument to me,

poetryblock.poem: and I will not respond to him with your arguments.

poem.verse: 15Job’s friends are dismayed and can no longer answer;

poetryblock.poem: words have left them.

poem.verse: 16Should I continue to wait now that they are silent,

poetryblock.poem: now that they stand there and no longer answer?

poem.verse: 17I too will answer;

poetryblock.poem: yes, I will tell what I know.

poem.verse: 18For I am full of words,

poetryblock.poem: and my spirit compels me to speak.

poem.verse: 19My heart is like bottled-up wine;

poetryblock.poem: it is about to burst like new wineskins.

poem.verse: 20I must speak so that I can find relief;

poetryblock.poem: I must open my lips and respond.

poem.verse: 21I will be partial to no one,

poetryblock.poem: and I will not give anyone an undeserved title.

poem.verse: 22For I do not know how to give such titles;

poetryblock.poem: otherwise, my Maker would remove me in an instant.

poem.verse: 1But now, Job, pay attention to my speech,

poetryblock.poem: and listen to all my words.

poem.verse: 2I am going to open my mouth;

poetryblock.poem: my tongue will form words on my palate.

poem.verse: 3My words come from my upright heart,

poetryblock.poem: and my lips speak with sincerity what they know.

poem.verse: 4The Spirit of God has made me,

poetryblock.poem: and the breath of the Almighty gives me life.

poem.verse: 5Refute me if you can.

poetryblock.poem: Prepare your case against me; take your stand.

poem.verse: 6I am just like you before God;

poetryblock.poem: I was also pinched off from a piece of clay.

poem.verse: 7Fear of me should not terrify you;

poetryblock.poem: no pressure from me should weigh you down.

poem.verse: 8Surely you have spoken in my hearing,

poetryblock.poem: and I have heard these very words:

poem.verse: 9‘I am pure, without transgression;

poetryblock.poem: I am clean and have no iniquity.

poem.verse: 10But he finds reasons to oppose me;

poetryblock.poem: he regards me as his enemy.

poem.verse: 11He puts my feet in the stocks;

poetryblock.poem: he stands watch over all my paths.’

poem.verse: 12But I tell you that you are wrong in this matter,

poetryblock.poem: since God is greater than man.

poem.verse: 13Why do you take him to court

poetryblock.poem: for not answering anything a person asks?

poem.verse: 14For God speaks time and again,

poetryblock.poem: but a person may not notice it.

poem.verse: 15In a dream, a vision in the night,

poetryblock.poem: when deep sleep comes over people
as they slumber on their beds,

poem.verse: 16he uncovers their ears

poetryblock.poem: and terrifies them with warnings,

poem.verse: 17in order to turn a person from his actions

poetryblock.poem: and suppress the pride of a person.

poem.verse: 18God spares his soul from the Pit,

poetryblock.poem: his life from crossing the river of death.

poem.verse: 19A person may be disciplined on his bed with pain

poetryblock.poem: and constant distress in his bones,

poem.verse: 20so that he detests bread,

poetryblock.poem: and his soul despises his favourite food.

poem.verse: 21His flesh wastes away to nothing,

poetryblock.poem: and his unseen bones stick out.

poem.verse: 22He draws near to the Pit,

poetryblock.poem: and his life to the executioners.

poem.verse: 23If there is an angel on his side,

poetryblock.poem: one mediator out of a thousand,
to tell a person what is right for him

poem.verse: 24and to be gracious to him and say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘Spare him from going down to the Pit;
I have found a ransom,’

poem.verse: 25then his flesh will be healthier than in his youth,

poetryblock.poem: and he will return to the days of his youthful vigour.

poem.verse: 26He will pray to God, and God will delight in him.

poetryblock.poem: That person will see his face with a shout of joy,
and God will restore his righteousness to him.

poem.verse: 27He will look at men and say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I have sinned and perverted what was right;
yet I did not get what I deserved.

poem.verse: 28He redeemed my soul from going down to the Pit,

poetryblock.poem: and I will continue to see the light.’

poem.verse: 29God certainly does all these things

poetryblock.poem: two or three times to a person

poem.verse: 30in order to turn him back from the Pit,

poetryblock.poem: so he may shine with the light of life.

poem.verse: 31Pay attention, Job, and listen to me.

poetryblock.poem: Be quiet, and I will speak.

poem.verse: 32But if you have something to say, answer me;

poetryblock.poem: speak, for I would like to justify you.

poem.verse: 33If not, then listen to me;

poetryblock.poem: be quiet, and I will teach you wisdom.

p.verse: 1Then Elihu continued, saying:

poem.verse: 2Hear my words, you wise ones,

poetryblock.poem: and listen to me, you knowledgeable ones.

poem.verse: 3Doesn’t the ear test words

poetryblock.poem: as the palate tastes food?

poem.verse: 4Let us judge for ourselves what is right;

poetryblock.poem: let us decide together what is good.

poem.verse: 5For Job has declared, ‘I am righteous,

poetryblock.poem: yet God has deprived me of justice.

poem.verse: 6Would I lie about my case?

poetryblock.poem: My wound is incurable,
though I am without transgression.’

poem.verse: 7What man is like Job?

poetryblock.poem: He drinks derision like water.

poem.verse: 8He keeps company with evildoers

poetryblock.poem: and walks with wicked men.

poem.verse: 9For he has said, ‘A man gains nothing

poetryblock.poem: when he becomes God’s friend.’

poem.verse: 10Therefore listen to me, you men of understanding.

poetryblock.poem: It is impossible for God to do wrong,
and for the Almighty to act unjustly.

poem.verse: 11For he repays a person according to his deeds,

poetryblock.poem: and he gives him what his conduct deserves.

poem.verse: 12Indeed, it is true that God does not act wickedly

poetryblock.poem: and the Almighty does not pervert justice.

poem.verse: 13Who gave him authority over the earth?

poetryblock.poem: Who put him in charge of the entire world?

poem.verse: 14If he put his mind to it

poetryblock.poem: and withdrew the spirit and breath he gave,

poem.verse: 15every living thing would perish together

poetryblock.poem: and mankind would return to the dust.

poem.verse: 16If you have understanding, hear this;

poetryblock.poem: listen to what I have to say.

poem.verse: 17Could one who hates justice govern the world?

poetryblock.poem: Will you condemn the mighty Righteous One,

poem.verse: 18who says to a king, ‘Worthless man! ’

poetryblock.poem: and to nobles, ‘Wicked men! ’?

poem.verse: 19God is not partial to princes

poetryblock.poem: and does not favour the rich over the poor,
for they are all the work of his hands.

poem.verse: 20They die suddenly in the middle of the night;

poetryblock.poem: people shudder, then pass away.
Even the mighty are removed without effort.

poem.verse: 21For his eyes watch over a man’s ways,

poetryblock.poem: and he observes all his steps.

poem.verse: 22There is no darkness, no deep darkness,

poetryblock.poem: where evildoers can hide.

poem.verse: 23God does not need to examine a person further,

poetryblock.poem: that one should approach him in court.

poem.verse: 24He shatters the mighty without an investigation

poetryblock.poem: and sets others in their place.

poem.verse: 25Therefore, he recognises their deeds

poetryblock.poem: and overthrows them by night, and they are crushed.

poem.verse: 26In full view of the public,

poetryblock.poem: he strikes them for their wickedness,

poem.verse: 27because they turned aside from following him

poetryblock.poem: and did not understand any of his ways

poem.verse: 28but caused the poor to cry out to him,

poetryblock.poem: and he heard the outcry of the needy.

poem.verse: 29But when God is silent, who can declare him guilty?

poetryblock.poem: When he hides his face, who can see him?
Yet he watches over both individuals and nations,

poem.verse: 30so that godless men should not rule

poetryblock.poem: or ensnare the people.

poem.verse: 31Suppose someone says to God,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I have endured my punishment;
I will no longer act wickedly.

poem.verse: 32Teach me what I cannot see;

poetryblock.poem: if I have done wrong, I won’t do it again.’

poem.verse: 33Should God repay you on your terms

poetryblock.poem: when you have rejected his?
You must choose, not I!
So declare what you know.

poem.verse: 34Reasonable men will say to me,

poetryblock.poem: along with the wise men who hear me,

poem.verse: 35‘Job speaks without knowledge;

poetryblock.poem: his words are without insight.’

poem.verse: 36If only Job were tested to the limit,

poetryblock.poem: because his answers are like those of wicked men.

poem.verse: 37For he adds rebellion to his sin;

poetryblock.poem: he scornfully claps in our presence,
while multiplying his words against God.

p.verse: 1Then Elihu continued, saying:

poem.verse: 2Do you think it is just when you say,

poetryblock.poem: ‘I am righteous before God’?

poem.verse: 3For you ask, ‘What does it profit you,

poetryblock.poem: and what benefit comes to me, if I do not sin? ’

poem.verse: 4I will answer you

poetryblock.poem: and your friends with you.

poem.verse: 5Look at the heavens and see;

poetryblock.poem: gaze at the clouds high above you.

poem.verse: 6If you sin, how does it affect God?

poetryblock.poem: If you multiply your transgressions, what does it do to him?

poem.verse: 7If you are righteous, what do you give him,

poetryblock.poem: or what does he receive from your hand?

poem.verse: 8Your wickedness affects a person like yourself,

poetryblock.poem: and your righteousness, a son of man.

poem.verse: 9People cry out because of severe oppression;

poetryblock.poem: they shout for help because of the power of the mighty.

poem.verse: 10But no one asks, ‘Where is God my Maker,

poetryblock.poem: who provides us with songs in the night,

poem.verse: 11who gives us more understanding than the animals of the earth

poetryblock.poem: and makes us wiser than the birds of the sky? ’

poem.verse: 12There they cry out, but he does not answer,

poetryblock.poem: because of the pride of evil people.

poem.verse: 13Indeed, God does not listen to empty cries,

poetryblock.poem: and the Almighty does not take note of it –

poem.verse: 14how much less when you complain

poetryblock.poem: that you do not see him,
that your case is before him
and you are waiting for him.

poem.verse: 15But now, because God’s anger does not punish

poetryblock.poem: and he does not pay attention to transgression,

poem.verse: 16Job opens his mouth in vain

poetryblock.poem: and multiplies words without knowledge.

p.verse: 1Then Elihu continued, saying:

poem.verse: 2Be patient with me a little longer, and I will inform you,

poetryblock.poem: for there is still more to be said on God’s behalf.

poem.verse: 3I will get my knowledge from a distant place

poetryblock.poem: and ascribe justice to my Maker.

poem.verse: 4Indeed, my words are not false;

poetryblock.poem: one who has complete knowledge is with you.

poem.verse: 5Yes, God is mighty, but he despises no one;

poetryblock.poem: he understands all things.

poem.verse: 6He does not keep the wicked alive,

poetryblock.poem: but he gives justice to the oppressed.

poem.verse: 7He does not withdraw his gaze from the righteous,

poetryblock.poem: but he seats them for ever with enthroned kings,
and they are exalted.

poem.verse: 8If people are bound with chains

poetryblock.poem: and trapped by the cords of affliction,

poem.verse: 9God tells them what they have done

poetryblock.poem: and how arrogantly they have transgressed.

poem.verse: 10He opens their ears to correction

poetryblock.poem: and tells them to repent from iniquity.

poem.verse: 11If they listen and serve him,

poetryblock.poem: they will end their days in prosperity
and their years in happiness.

poem.verse: 12But if they do not listen,

poetryblock.poem: they will cross the river of death
and die without knowledge.

poem.verse: 13Those who have a godless heart harbour anger;

poetryblock.poem: even when God binds them, they do not cry for help.

poem.verse: 14They die in their youth;

poetryblock.poem: their life ends among male cult prostitutes.

poem.verse: 15God rescues the afflicted by their affliction;

poetryblock.poem: he instructs them by their torment.

poem.verse: 16Indeed, he lured you from the jaws of distress

poetryblock.poem: to a spacious and unconfined place.
Your table was spread with choice food.

poem.verse: 17Yet now you are obsessed with the judgement due the wicked;

poetryblock.poem: judgement and justice have seized you.

poem.verse: 18Be careful that no one lures you with riches;

poetryblock.poem: do not let a large ransom lead you astray.

poem.verse: 19Can your wealth or all your physical exertion

poetryblock.poem: keep you from distress?

poem.verse: 20Do not long for the night

poetryblock.poem: when nations will disappear from their places.

poem.verse: 21Be careful that you do not turn to iniquity,

poetryblock.poem: for that is why you have been tested by affliction.

poem.verse: 22Look, God shows himself exalted by his power.

poetryblock.poem: Who is a teacher like him?

poem.verse: 23Who has appointed his way for him,

poetryblock.poem: and who has declared, ‘You have done wrong’?

poem.verse: 24Remember that you should praise his work,

poetryblock.poem: which people have sung about.

poem.verse: 25All mankind has seen it;

poetryblock.poem: people have looked at it from a distance.

poem.verse: 26Yes, God is exalted beyond our knowledge;

poetryblock.poem: the number of his years cannot be counted.

poem.verse: 27For he makes waterdrops evaporate;

poetryblock.poem: they distil the rain into its mist,

poem.verse: 28which the clouds pour out

poetryblock.poem: and shower abundantly on mankind.

poem.verse: 29Can anyone understand how the clouds spread out

poetryblock.poem: or how the thunder roars from God’s pavilion?

poem.verse: 30See how he spreads his lightning around him

poetryblock.poem: and covers the depths of the sea.

poem.verse: 31For he judges the nations with these;

poetryblock.poem: he gives food in abundance.

poem.verse: 32He covers his hands with lightning

poetryblock.poem: and commands it to hit its mark.

poem.verse: 33The thunder declares his presence;

poetryblock.poem: the cattle also, the approaching storm.

poem.verse: 1My heart pounds at this

poetryblock.poem: and leaps from my chest.

poem.verse: 2Just listen to his thunderous voice

poetryblock.poem: and the rumbling that comes from his mouth.

poem.verse: 3He lets it loose beneath the entire sky;

poetryblock.poem: his lightning to the ends of the earth.

poem.verse: 4Then there comes a roaring sound;

poetryblock.poem: God thunders with his majestic voice.
He does not restrain the lightning
when his rumbling voice is heard.

poem.verse: 5God thunders wondrously with his voice;

poetryblock.poem: he does great things that we cannot comprehend.

poem.verse: 6For he says to the snow, ‘Fall to the earth,’

poetryblock.poem: and the torrential rains, his mighty torrential rains,

poem.verse: 7serve as his sign to all mankind,

poetryblock.poem: so that all men may know his work.

poem.verse: 8The wild animals enter their lairs

poetryblock.poem: and stay in their dens.

poem.verse: 9The windstorm comes from its chamber,

poetryblock.poem: and the cold from the driving north winds.

poem.verse: 10Ice is formed by the breath of God,

poetryblock.poem: and watery expanses are frozen.

poem.verse: 11He saturates clouds with moisture;

poetryblock.poem: he scatters his lightning through them.

poem.verse: 12They swirl about,

poetryblock.poem: turning round and round at his direction,
accomplishing everything he commands them
over the surface of the inhabited world.

poem.verse: 13He causes this to happen for punishment,

poetryblock.poem: for his land, or for his faithful love.

poem.verse: 14Listen to this, Job.

poetryblock.poem: Stop and consider God’s wonders.

poem.verse: 15Do you know how God directs his clouds

poetryblock.poem: or makes their lightning flash?

poem.verse: 16Do you understand how the clouds float,

poetryblock.poem: those wonderful works of him who has perfect knowledge?

poem.verse: 17You whose clothes get hot

poetryblock.poem: when the south wind brings calm to the land,

poem.verse: 18can you help God spread out the skies

poetryblock.poem: as hard as a cast metal mirror?

poem.verse: 19Teach us what we should say to him;

poetryblock.poem: we cannot prepare our case because of our darkness.

poem.verse: 20Should he be told that I want to speak?

poetryblock.poem: Can a man speak when he is confused?

poem.verse: 21Now no one can even look at the sun

poetryblock.poem: after a wind has swept through and cleared the sky.

poem.verse: 22Out of the north he comes, shrouded in a golden glow;

poetryblock.poem: awesome majesty surrounds him.

poem.verse: 23The Almighty ​– ​we cannot reach him –

poetryblock.poem: he is exalted in power!
He will not violate justice and abundant righteousness,

poem.verse: 24therefore, men fear him.

poetryblock.poem: He does not look favourably on any who are wise in heart.

p.verse: 1Then the Lord answered Job from the whirlwind. He said:

poem.verse: 2Who is this who obscures my counsel

poetryblock.poem: with ignorant words?

poem.verse: 3Get ready to answer me like a man;

poetryblock.poem: when I question you, you will inform me.

poem.verse: 4Where were you when I established the earth?

poetryblock.poem: Tell me, if you have understanding.

poem.verse: 5Who fixed its dimensions? Certainly you know!

poetryblock.poem: Who stretched a measuring line across it?

poem.verse: 6What supports its foundations?

poetryblock.poem: Or who laid its cornerstone

poem.verse: 7while the morning stars sang together

poetryblock.poem: and all the sons of God shouted for joy?

poem.verse: 8Who enclosed the sea behind doors

poetryblock.poem: when it burst from the womb,

poem.verse: 9when I made the clouds its garment

poetryblock.poem: and total darkness its blanket,

poem.verse: 10when I determined its boundaries

poetryblock.poem: and put its bars and doors in place,

poem.verse: 11when I declared, ‘You may come this far, but no further;

poetryblock.poem: your proud waves stop here’?

poem.verse: 12Have you ever in your life commanded the morning

poetryblock.poem: or assigned the dawn its place,

poem.verse: 13so it may seize the edges of the earth

poetryblock.poem: and shake the wicked out of it?

poem.verse: 14The earth is changed as clay is by a seal;

poetryblock.poem: its hills stand out like the folds of a garment.

poem.verse: 15Light is withheld from the wicked,

poetryblock.poem: and the arm raised in violence is broken.

poem.verse: 16Have you travelled to the sources of the sea

poetryblock.poem: or walked in the depths of the oceans?

poem.verse: 17Have the gates of death been revealed to you?

poetryblock.poem: Have you seen the gates of deep darkness?

poem.verse: 18Have you comprehended the extent of the earth?

poetryblock.poem: Tell me, if you know all this.

poem.verse: 19Where is the road to the home of light?

poetryblock.poem: Do you know where darkness lives,

poem.verse: 20so you can lead it back to its border?

poetryblock.poem: Are you familiar with the paths to its home?

poem.verse: 21Don’t you know? You were already born;

poetryblock.poem: you have lived so long!

poem.verse: 22Have you entered the place where the snow is stored?

poetryblock.poem: Or have you seen the storehouses of hail,

poem.verse: 23which I hold in reserve for times of trouble,

poetryblock.poem: for the day of warfare and battle?

poem.verse: 24What road leads to the place where light is dispersed?

poetryblock.poem: Where is the source of the east wind that spreads across the earth?

poem.verse: 25Who cuts a channel for the flooding rain

poetryblock.poem: or clears the way for lightning,

poem.verse: 26to bring rain on an uninhabited land,

poetryblock.poem: on a desert with no human life,

poem.verse: 27to satisfy the parched wasteland

poetryblock.poem: and cause the grass to sprout?

poem.verse: 28Does the rain have a father?

poetryblock.poem: Who fathered the drops of dew?

poem.verse: 29Whose womb did the ice come from?

poetryblock.poem: Who gave birth to the frost of heaven

poem.verse: 30when water becomes as hard as stone,

poetryblock.poem: and the surface of the watery depths is frozen?

poem.verse: 31Can you fasten the chains of the Pleiades

poetryblock.poem: or loosen the belt of Orion?

poem.verse: 32Can you bring out the constellations in their season

poetryblock.poem: and lead the Bear and her cubs?

poem.verse: 33Do you know the laws of heaven?

poetryblock.poem: Can you impose its authority on earth?

poem.verse: 34Can you command the clouds

poetryblock.poem: so that a flood of water covers you?

poem.verse: 35Can you send out lightning bolts, and they go?

poetryblock.poem: Do they report to you, ‘Here we are’?

poem.verse: 36Who put wisdom in the heart

poetryblock.poem: or gave the mind understanding?

poem.verse: 37Who has the wisdom to number the clouds?

poetryblock.poem: Or who can tilt the water jars of heaven

poem.verse: 38when the dust hardens like cast metal

poetryblock.poem: and the clods of soil stick together?

poem.verse: 39Can you hunt prey for a lioness

poetryblock.poem: or satisfy the appetite of young lions

poem.verse: 40when they crouch in their dens

poetryblock.poem: and lie in wait within their lairs?

poem.verse: 41Who provides the raven’s food

poetryblock.poem: when its young cry out to God
and wander about for lack of food?

poem.verse: 1Do you know when mountain goats give birth?

poetryblock.poem: Have you watched the deer in labour?

poem.verse: 2Can you count the months they are pregnant

poetryblock.poem: so you can know the time they give birth?

poem.verse: 3They crouch down to give birth to their young;

poetryblock.poem: they deliver their newborn.

poem.verse: 4Their offspring are healthy and grow up in the open field.

poetryblock.poem: They leave and do not return.

poem.verse: 5Who set the wild donkey free?

poetryblock.poem: Who released the swift donkey from its harness?

poem.verse: 6I made the desert its home,

poetryblock.poem: and the salty wasteland its dwelling.

poem.verse: 7It scoffs at the noise of the village

poetryblock.poem: and never hears the shouts of a driver.

poem.verse: 8It roams the mountains for its pastureland,

poetryblock.poem: searching for anything green.

poem.verse: 9Would the wild ox be willing to serve you?

poetryblock.poem: Would it spend the night by your feeding trough?

poem.verse: 10Can you hold the wild ox to a furrow by its harness?

poetryblock.poem: Will it plough the valleys behind you?

poem.verse: 11Can you depend on it because its strength is great?

poetryblock.poem: Would you leave it to do your hard work?

poem.verse: 12Can you trust the wild ox to harvest your corn

poetryblock.poem: and bring it to your threshing-floor?

poem.verse: 13The wings of the ostrich flap joyfully,

poetryblock.poem: but are her feathers and plumage like the stork’s?

poem.verse: 14She abandons her eggs on the ground

poetryblock.poem: and lets them be warmed in the sand.

poem.verse: 15She forgets that a foot may crush them

poetryblock.poem: or that some wild animal may trample them.

poem.verse: 16She treats her young harshly, as if they were not her own,

poetryblock.poem: with no fear that her labour may have been in vain.

poem.verse: 17For God has deprived her of wisdom;

poetryblock.poem: he has not endowed her with understanding.

poem.verse: 18When she proudly spreads her wings,

poetryblock.poem: she laughs at the horse and its rider.

poem.verse: 19Do you give strength to the horse?

poetryblock.poem: Do you adorn his neck with a mane?

poem.verse: 20Do you make him leap like a locust?

poetryblock.poem: His proud snorting fills one with terror.

poem.verse: 21He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength;

poetryblock.poem: he charges into battle.

poem.verse: 22He laughs at fear, since he is afraid of nothing;

poetryblock.poem: he does not run from the sword.

poem.verse: 23A quiver rattles at his side,

poetryblock.poem: along with a flashing spear and a javelin.

poem.verse: 24He charges ahead with trembling rage;

poetryblock.poem: he cannot stand still at the sound of the ram’s horn.

poem.verse: 25When the ram’s horn blasts, he snorts defiantly.

poetryblock.poem: He smells the battle from a distance;
he hears the officers’ shouts and the battle cry.

poem.verse: 26Does the hawk take flight by your understanding

poetryblock.poem: and spread its wings to the south?

poem.verse: 27Does the eagle soar at your command

poetryblock.poem: and make its nest on high?

poem.verse: 28It lives on a cliff where it spends the night;

poetryblock.poem: its stronghold is on a rocky crag.

poem.verse: 29From there it searches for prey;

poetryblock.poem: its eyes penetrate the distance.

poem.verse: 30Its brood gulps down blood,

poetryblock.poem: and where the slain are, it is there.

p.verse: 1The Lord answered Job:

poem.verse: 2Will the one who contends with the Almighty correct him?

poetryblock.poem: Let him who argues with God give an answer.

p.verse: 3Then Job answered the Lord:

poem.verse: 4I am so insignificant. How can I answer you?

poetryblock.poem: I place my hand over my mouth.

poem.verse: 5I have spoken once, and I will not reply;

poetryblock.poem: twice, but now I can add nothing.

p.verse: 6Then the Lord answered Job from the whirlwind:

poem.verse: 7Get ready to answer me like a man;

poetryblock.poem: when I question you, you will inform me.

poem.verse: 8Would you really challenge my justice?

poetryblock.poem: Would you declare me guilty to justify yourself?

poem.verse: 9Do you have an arm like God’s?

poetryblock.poem: Can you thunder with a voice like his?

poem.verse: 10Adorn yourself with majesty and splendour,

poetryblock.poem: and clothe yourself with honour and glory.

poem.verse: 11Pour out your raging anger;

poetryblock.poem: look on every proud person and humiliate him.

poem.verse: 12Look on every proud person and humble him;

poetryblock.poem: trample the wicked where they stand.

poem.verse: 13Hide them together in the dust;

poetryblock.poem: imprison them in the grave.

poem.verse: 14Then I will confess to you

poetryblock.poem: that your own right hand can deliver you.

poem.verse: 15Look at Behemoth,

poetryblock.poem: which I made along with you.
He eats grass like cattle.

poem.verse: 16Look at the strength of his back

poetryblock.poem: and the power in the muscles of his belly.

poem.verse: 17He stiffens his tail like a cedar tree;

poetryblock.poem: the tendons of his thighs are woven firmly together.

poem.verse: 18His bones are bronze tubes;

poetryblock.poem: his limbs are like iron rods.

poem.verse: 19He is the foremost of God’s works;

poetryblock.poem: only his Maker can draw the sword against him.

poem.verse: 20The hills yield food for him,

poetryblock.poem: while all sorts of wild animals play there.

poem.verse: 21He lies under the lotus plants,

poetryblock.poem: hiding in the protection of marshy reeds.

poem.verse: 22Lotus plants cover him with their shade;

poetryblock.poem: the willows by the brook surround him.

poem.verse: 23Though the river rages, Behemoth is unafraid;

poetryblock.poem: he remains confident, even if the Jordan surges up to his mouth.

poem.verse: 24Can anyone capture him while he looks on,

poetryblock.poem: or pierce his nose with snares?

poem.verse: 1Can you pull in Leviathan with a hook

poetryblock.poem: or tie his tongue down with a rope?

poem.verse: 2Can you put a cord through his nose

poetryblock.poem: or pierce his jaw with a hook?

poem.verse: 3Will he beg you for mercy

poetryblock.poem: or speak softly to you?

poem.verse: 4Will he make a covenant with you

poetryblock.poem: so that you can take him as a slave for ever?

poem.verse: 5Can you play with him like a bird

poetryblock.poem: or put him on a leash for your girls?

poem.verse: 6Will traders bargain for him

poetryblock.poem: or divide him among the merchants?

poem.verse: 7Can you fill his hide with harpoons

poetryblock.poem: or his head with fishing spears?

poem.verse: 8Lay a hand on him.

poetryblock.poem: You will remember the battle
and never repeat it!

poem.verse: 9Any hope of capturing him proves false.

poetryblock.poem: Does a person not collapse at the very sight of him?

poem.verse: 10No one is ferocious enough to rouse Leviathan;

poetryblock.poem: who then can stand against me?

poem.verse: 11Who confronted me, that I should repay him?

poetryblock.poem: Everything under heaven belongs to me.

poem.verse: 12I cannot be silent about his limbs,

poetryblock.poem: his power, and his graceful proportions.

poem.verse: 13Who can strip off his outer covering?

poetryblock.poem: Who can penetrate his double layer of armour?

poem.verse: 14Who can open his jaws,

poetryblock.poem: surrounded by those terrifying teeth?

poem.verse: 15His pride is in his rows of scales,

poetryblock.poem: closely sealed together.

poem.verse: 16One scale is so close to another

poetryblock.poem: that no air can pass between them.

poem.verse: 17They are joined to one another,

poetryblock.poem: so closely connected they cannot be separated.

poem.verse: 18His snorting flashes with light,

poetryblock.poem: while his eyes are like the rays of dawn.

poem.verse: 19Flaming torches shoot from his mouth;

poetryblock.poem: fiery sparks fly out!

poem.verse: 20Smoke billows from his nostrils

poetryblock.poem: as from a boiling pot or burning reeds.

poem.verse: 21His breath sets coals ablaze,

poetryblock.poem: and flames pour out of his mouth.

poem.verse: 22Strength resides in his neck,

poetryblock.poem: and dismay dances before him.

poem.verse: 23The folds of his flesh are joined together,

poetryblock.poem: solid as metal and immovable.

poem.verse: 24His heart is as hard as a rock,

poetryblock.poem: as hard as a lower millstone!

poem.verse: 25When Leviathan rises, the mighty are terrified;

poetryblock.poem: they withdraw because of his thrashing.

poem.verse: 26The sword that reaches him will have no effect,

poetryblock.poem: nor will a spear, dart, or arrow.

poem.verse: 27He regards iron as straw,

poetryblock.poem: and bronze as rotten wood.

poem.verse: 28No arrow can make him flee;

poetryblock.poem: slingstones become like stubble to him.

poem.verse: 29A club is regarded as stubble,

poetryblock.poem: and he laughs at the sound of a javelin.

poem.verse: 30His undersides are jagged potsherds,

poetryblock.poem: spreading the mud like a threshing sledge.

poem.verse: 31He makes the depths seethe like a cauldron;

poetryblock.poem: he makes the sea like an ointment jar.

poem.verse: 32He leaves a shining wake behind him;

poetryblock.poem: one would think the deep had grey hair!

poem.verse: 33He has no equal on earth –

poetryblock.poem: a creature devoid of fear!

poem.verse: 34He surveys everything that is haughty;

poetryblock.poem: he is king over all the proud beasts.

p.verse: 1Then Job replied to the Lord:

poem.verse: 2I know that you can do anything

poetryblock.poem: and no plan of yours can be thwarted.

poem.verse: 3You asked, ‘Who is this who conceals my counsel with ignorance? ’

poetryblock.poem: Surely I spoke about things I did not understand,
things too wondrous for me to know.

poem.verse: 4You said, ‘Listen now, and I will speak.

poetryblock.poem: When I question you, you will inform me.’

poem.verse: 5I had heard reports about you,

poetryblock.poem: but now my eyes have seen you.

poem.verse: 6Therefore, I reject my words and am sorry for them;

poetryblock.poem: I am dust and ashes.

p.verse: 7After the Lord had finished speaking to Job, he said to Eliphaz the Temanite, ‘I am angry with you and your two friends, for you have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.

8Now take seven bulls and seven rams, go to my servant Job, and offer a burnt offering for yourselves. Then my servant Job will pray for you. I will surely accept his prayer and not deal with you as your folly deserves. For you have not spoken the truth about me, as my servant Job has.’
9Then Eliphaz the Temanite, Bildad the Shuhite, and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the Lord had told them, and the Lord accepted Job’s prayer.
10After Job had prayed for his friends, the Lord restored his fortunes and doubled his previous possessions.

11All his brothers, sisters, and former acquaintances came to him and dined with him in his house. They sympathised with him and comforted him concerning all the adversity the Lord had brought on him. Each one gave him a piece of silver and a gold earring.
12So the Lord blessed the last part of Job’s life more than the first. He owned fourteen thousand sheep and goats, six thousand camels, one thousand yoke of oxen, and one thousand female donkeys.
13He also had seven sons and three daughters.
14He named his first daughter Jemimah, his second Keziah, and his third Keren-happuch.
15No women as beautiful as Job’s daughters could be found in all the land, and their father granted them an inheritance with their brothers.
16Job lived for 140 years after this and saw his children and their children to the fourth generation.
17Then Job died, old and full of days.
